    Synthesis and Biological Evaluation of Phosphoester and Phosphorothioate Prodrugs of STING Agonist 3′,3′-c-Di(2′F,2′dAMP)

    SUBJECTS:

    Get e-Alerts

    Abstract

    Cyclic dinucleotides (CDNs) are second messengers that bind to the stimulator of interferon genes (STING) and trigger the expression of type I interferons and proinflammatory cytokines. Here we evaluate the activity of 3′,3′-c-di(2′F,2′dAMP) and its phosphorothioate analogues against five STING allelic forms in reporter-cell-based assays and rationalize our findings with X-ray crystallography and quantum mechanics/molecular mechanics calculations. We show that the presence of fluorine in the 2′ position of 3′,3′-c-di(2′F,2′dAMP) improves its activity not only against the wild type (WT) but also against REF and Q STING. Additionally, we describe the synthesis of the acyloxymethyl and isopropyloxycarbonyl phosphoester prodrugs of CDNs. Masking the negative charges of the CDNs results in an up to a 1000-fold improvement of the activities of the prodrugs relative to those of their parent CDNs. Finally, the uptake and intracellular cleavage of pivaloyloxymethyl prodrugs to the parent CDN is rapid, reaching a peak intracellular concentration within 2 h.

    Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Sensing double-stranded DNA (dsDNA) in cytoplasm is one of the crucial innate immunity mechanisms that protects an organism from pathogens and cell damage.(1,2) Several sensors of cytosolic dsDNA have been identified, including the cyclic-GMP-AMP synthase (cGAS), the absent in melanoma 2 (AIM2), the interferon-inducible protein 16 (IFI16), the DEAD box protein 41 (DDX41), and others, all of which trigger different signaling cascades. It was later shown that cGAS is the central cytosolic dsDNA sensor, and the cGAS-STING pathway is crucial for the cytosolic dsDNA-triggered signaling.(1,2) Upon binding to dsDNA, the cGAS enzyme converts GTP and ATP into a cyclic dinucleotide (CDN) with 2′-5′ and 3′-5′ phosphodiester linkages called cyclic-GMP-AMP (2′,3′-cGAMP).(3−5) This second messenger then binds to a homodimeric adaptor protein called the stimulator of interferon genes (STING, also known as MITA, TMEM173, ERIS, or MPYS) on the endoplasmic reticulum (ER).(6−9) STING then translocates to the ER-Golgi intermediate compartment and the Golgi apparatus(10,11) and undergoes conformational changes that allow the formation of tetramers and higher-order oligomers.(12) These changes facilitate the recruitment of TANK-binding kinase 1 (TBK1) to STING and trigger the TBK1-mediated phosphorylation of STING, leading to the binding of a transcription factor interferon regulatory factor 3 (IRF3).(13,14) IRF3 is further activated by the TBK1-mediated phosphorylation, which results in the IRF3 homodimerization, the migration to the cell nucleus, and the induction of type I interferon gene transcription.(1,13) In parallel, STING and TBK1 also interact with inhibitors of κB kinases (IKKs), the key regulators of nuclear factor κB (NFκB).(14) IKKs release the transcription factor NFκB from its inhibitor, thus allowing the transcription of proinflammatory cytokines and chemokines such as tumor necrosis factor-α (TNFα) and interleukin 6 (IL6).(15) The released type I interferons and proinflammatory cytokines interact with their receptors on the cell surface, triggering the immune defense against invading pathogens, especially viruses.(16) Furthermore, the activation of the cGAS-STING pathway by a host dsDNA has also been shown to play an important role in the induction of antitumor immunity.(1,16−18) Apart from the eukaryotic 2′,3′-cGAMP, protein STING can also bind CDNs produced by prokaryotes. The CDNs contain two 3′-5′ phosphodiester bonds that connect two nucleotides, which can be both AMP, both GMP, or a combination.(19,20) The activation of the cGAS-STING pathway by bacterial CDNs is important for the immune defense against intracellular bacteria.(1,20)
    In general, CDNs are polar molecules bearing two negative charges on the phosphoric oxygen atoms, and their cellular uptake requires the presence of transporters since the free diffusion of polar molecules via the lipid cell membrane is limited.(21) For a successful drug design, the negative charges of CDNs need to be masked to increase their ability to enter cells via diffusion through the cell membrane. Several prodrug strategies were developed to improve the transport of polar nucleoside phosphates and phosphonates across the cell membrane to cells, where the biolabile protecting groups are enzymatically degraded or spontaneously cleaved in an intracellular environment and the active parent species is released. The carbonyloxymethyl prodrugs of acyclic nucleoside phosphonates (adefovir dipivoxil, bis(POM)PMEA, and tenofovir disoproxil fumarate, bis(POC)PMPA;(22,23)Figure 1) and aryloxy phosphoramidate prodrugs (ProTide technology, e.g., sofosbuvir(24) or tenofovir alafenamide;(25)Figure 1) belong to a group of clinically validated and FDA-approved drugs. Several bis(POM), bis(POC), and acyloxybenzyl prodrugs of phosphorothioate CDNs are exemplified in the patent literature.(26−30) However, to the best of our knowledge no prodrugs of phosphodiester CDNs have been published so far.
    Here we describe a synthesis of various acyloxymethyl and isopropyloxycarbonyloxymethyl (POM-like and POC) prodrugs of the 3′,3′-c-di(2′F,2′dAMP)(31) (1) and its phosphorothioate analogues 8 (Figure 2). We profiled their activities in cell-based reporter assays. To better understand the observed activities, we carried out physicochemical characterizations and structure–activity correlations of the parent phosphate (1) and the phosphorothioate CDNs (8 and 12) by employing a broad set of experimental and theoretical methods, such as differential scanning fluorimetry, X-ray crystallography, NMR measurements, and QM/MM modeling. All these techniques were used successfully in our previous studies of STING–ligand interactions.(32,33) To fully explore the therapeutic potential of our prodrugs, we investigated the effect of the tested compounds on human peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMC), a physiologically relevant cell population. Finally, we prepared tritium-labeled 3′,3′-c-di(2′F,2′dAMP) ([3H]-1) and its corresponding bis(POM) prodrugs ([3H]-4a) and compared their cellular uptakes.

    Results and Discussion

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    Synthesis and Characterization of CDNs and CDN-Derived Prodrugs

    Acyloxymethyl prodrugs of phosphates are prepared by the alkylation of an appropriate salt of the phosphate with acyloxymethyl halogenide. Various bases are used for the deprotonation of phosphates, e.g., amines such as triethylamine, N,N-diisopropylethylamine or DBU, carbonates, or tetrabutylammonium hydroxide.(34−36) Numerous salts of 3′,3′-c-di(2′F,2′dAMP) (1) were tested for the synthesis of CDN prodrugs. However, only tetrabutylammonium salts were reactive enough to afford dialkylated products. Triethylammonium, N,N-diisopropylethylammonium, and silver salts were unreactive or afforded only trace amounts of the monoalkylated products (data not shown). Acyloxymethyl iodides were used for the alkylation of tetrabutylammonium salts of 1, and the corresponding chlorides or bromides were not reactive enough for the alkylation. Iodomethyl pivalate (2a, POM-I),(37,38) iodomethyl 2-ethylbutanoate (2b),(39) iodomethyl benzoate (2c),(40,41) and isopropyl iodomethyl carbonate (2d)(37,38) were chosen as alkylation agents. The tetrabutylammonium salt of 1 was prepared using a solution of Bu4NOH in MeOH, and the resulting salt was dried and alkylated with the appropriate iodides 2a–2d in dry ACN at rt (Scheme 1). The choice of the solvent was crucial, as reactions in other solvents (e.g., DMF, DMA, or THF) proceeded with low conversions. The reaction afforded a mixture of monoalkylated products 3a–3d and dialkylated products (Rp,Sp)-4a–4d, (Rp,Rp)-4a, (Rp,Rp)-4b, and (Rp,Rp)-4d respectively. Three diastereoisomers of dialkylated 1 were detected in the reaction mixtures. However, one of them was only detected in trace amounts and was therefore not isolated. The most abundant diastereoisomers formed were the (Rp,Rp)-4a, (Rp,Rp)-4b, and (Rp,Rp)-4d derivatives (10–20% yields), and the less abundant diastereoisomers were the (Rp,Sp)-4a–4d derivatives (5–10% yields).
    The configurations of phosphorus atoms in compounds (Rp,Sp)-4a–4d, (Rp,Rp)-4a, (Rp,Rp)-4b, and (Rp,Rp)-4d were determined by NMR spectroscopy and DFT calculations (see below). The NMR spectra of compounds (Rp,Rp)-4a, (Rp,Rp)-4b, and (Rp,Rp)-4d contain one set of signals for both nucleotide units, i.e., the compound is symmetric with both POM units heading in the same direction (up or down). The spectra of compounds (Rp,Sp)-4a–4d contain two sets of signals, i.e., there is no symmetry in the compound, indicating the opposite orientations of the prodrug units (one up and one down) with the (Rp,Sp)-configuration of phosphorus atoms. The signals with the largest chemical shift changes between compounds (Rp,Sp)-4a and (Rp,Rp)-4a are the proton signals of the tert-butyl group, H2′ and H3′. A comparison with the DFT-calculated chemical shift differences indicates that, both POM grops are in the α-position (down from the macrocyclic ring and opposite to the nucleoside moieties) in compound (Rp,Rp)-4a; thus, the configuration of the phosphorus atom in (Rp,Rp)-4a is (Rp,Rp). The configuration of the phosphorus atom in the monoalkylated derivatives (Rp)-3a–3d is, according to the 31P NMR shifts, similar to those in the (Rp,Rp)-4a, (Rp,Rp)-4b, and (Rp,Rp)-4d derivatives; thus, it is in the (Rp)-configuration. These results are in good agreement with our experimental observation that less sterically hindered derivatives are formed more readily.
    The reaction with iodomethyl benzoate (2c) proceeded poorly compared to reactions with alkylation agents bearing an aliphatic substituent (2a, 2b, and 2d). The major isolated product was asymmetric (Rp,Sp)-4c in a 5% yield.
    The phosphorothioate counterparts of 3′,3′-c-di(2′F,2′dAMP) (1), 3′,3′-c-di[2′F,2′dAMP(S)] (8),(42,43) were prepared by cyclization(44−47) starting from commercially available phosphoramidite (5) and H-phosphonate (6)(48−50) (Scheme 2). Compound 6 was coupled with a free 5′-hydroxy group of 5 using 5-(ethylthio)-1H-tetrazole as a coupling agent in the presence of 3 Å molecular sieves. The resulting phosphite was sulfurized with a DDTT sulfurizing agent, and the 5′-DMTr protecting group of the crude linear dimer was deprotected with dichloroacetic acid in dichloromethane. The linear dimer 7 was cyclized using 5,5-dimethyl-2-oxo-2-chloro-1,3,2-dioxaphosphinane (DMOCP) in dry pyridine and treated with elemental sulfur to give three diastereoisomers of the protected cyclic phosphorothioate. Finally, the crude CDNs were deprotected with a solution of MeNH2 in EtOH, and the diastereoisomers were separated by reverse-phase preparative HPLC. The absolute configurations of the diastereoisomers of 8 were assigned using the combination of NMR spectroscopy and DFT calculations (see below) and later confirmed by X-ray crystallography.
    The synthesis of phosphorothioate prodrugs has been previously described in the literature.(26−28,51−53) The alkylation of phosphorothioates with alkyl iodides is chemoselective and is usually carried out in an aqueous solution in combination with an organic solvent (THF, acetone, or i-PrOH). The pivaloyloxymethyl prodrug was chosen as a model compound, and prodrugs 9 were prepared by the direct alkylation of 8 with POM-I (2a) in 50% aqueous acetonitrile at rt in moderate yields (40–50%; Scheme 2).
    Tritium-labeled 3′,3′-c-di(2′F,2′dAMP) ([3H]-1) at position 8 of the purine bases and the corresponding bis(POM) prodrugs [3H]-4a were prepared to study the cellular uptake and metabolism of the CDNs and their prodrugs, wherein the metabolism is defined as the intracellular cleavage of the prodrug moiety that results in a release of an active CDN. 3′,3′-c-Di(2′F,2′dAMP) (1) was brominated under acidic conditions in an acetate buffer at pH 4.0, and the 8-bromo derivative 10 was obtained in a 60% yield (Scheme 3).(54,55) Derivative [3H]-1 (36.7 mCi, 37.7 Ci/mmol) was synthesized via the reductive tritium debromination of the 8-bromo precursor 10 using carrier-free tritium gas (4.4 Ci, 164 GBq) catalyzed by PdO.(56−58) Furthermore, the 8-bromo derivative 10 was converted to the dialkylated bis(POM) prodrugs 11. Compound 10 was treated with Bu4NOH, and the corresponding tetrabutylammonium salt was alkylated with 2a in a manner similar to that of the unsubstituted 3′,3′-c-di(2′F,2′dAMP) (1). Surprisingly, the ratio of the three formed diastereoisomers (approximately 2:3:1) was different in comparison with that of the unsubstituted 3′,3′-c-di(2′F,2′dAMP) (1), and the most abundant isomer was the asymmetric derivative [3H]-(Rp,Sp)-4a. The reaction proceeded faster and with a better conversion than the reaction of the unsubstituted 1, and all three diastereoisomers [3H]-(Sp,Sp)-4a, [3H]-(Rp,Sp)-4a, and [3H]-(Rp,Rp)-4a were isolated. Tritiated bis-POM prodrugs [3H]-(Sp,Sp)-4a (13 mCi, 49.1 Ci/mmol), [3H]-(Rp,Sp)-4a (1.2 mCi, 48.4 Ci/mmol), and [3H]-(Rp,Rp)-4a (2.1 mCi, 45.3 Ci/mmol) were synthesized via the reductive tritium debromination of the precursors 11 using carrier-free tritium gas (4.4 Ci, 164 GBq) catalyzed by PdO. The ditritiated ligand was separated by HPLC purification on the reverse phase (Scheme 3).

    NMR Spectroscopy and DFT Calculations

    Three diastereoisomers of compound 8 ((Sp,Sp), (Rp,Sp), and (Rp,Rp)) were prepared. Two of them were symmetric (either both sulfur atoms down or both sulfur atoms up), and one was asymmetric with one sulfur atom up and one down. Proton and carbon NMR spectra immediately revealed that (Rp,Sp)-8 is an asymmetric diastereoisomer, since there are two sets of signals corresponding to units A and B of the dinucleotide (Figure 3). The configurations of the two symmetric diastereoisomers were determined by a comparison with the calculated chemical shift differences.
    The equilibrium (energy-minimized) structures of compounds 8 are shown in Figure 4, and the experimental and calculated chemical shifts are summarized in Tables S2 and S3, respectively. The assignment of experimental chemical shifts of units A and B in compound (Rp,Sp)-8 was done by a comparison with calculated data (Table 1). The hydrogen atom H2′, which is close in space to the thiophosphate sulfur atom, has a significantly larger chemical shift than that of H2′ close to the thiophosphate oxygen.
    Table 1. Experimental and Calculated (B3LYP/6-31+G(2d,p)) Chemical Shift Differences (ppm) between Units A and B of Molecule (Rp,Sp)-8a
     C3′C5′H2H8H2′H3′H5′a
    experiment–1.1–2.0–0.20.1–0.40.1–0.1
    calculation–0.9–2.00.00.1–0.50.10.0
    a

    The thiophosphate group in position 5′ of unit A has the sulfur atom heading down. Only carbon atoms with an experimental chemical shift difference larger than 1 ppm and hydrogen atoms with an experimental chemical shift difference larger than or equal to 0.1 are shown.

    In compound (Sp,Sp)-8, the chemical shift of hydrogen H2′ is larger than that in compound (Rp,Rp)-8, which indicates that the sulfur atoms in compound (Sp,Sp)-8 are in the β-position (up) and the configuration of the phosphorus atoms is (Sp,Sp). Similarly, the configuration of the phosphorus atoms in compound (Rp,Rp)-8 is (Rp,Rp) (in the α-position, down). This was further confirmed by a comparison of the experimental and calculated chemical shift differences between compounds (Sp,Sp)-8 and (Rp,Rp)-8. The largest experimental difference between carbon chemical shifts was found for C5′ (−2.2 ppm), which is in excellent agreement with the calculated difference of −2.1 ppm. The largest chemical shift differences for the monosaccharide protons were found for H1′ (0.2 ppm), H2′ (0.2 ppm), and H3′ (−0.2 ppm). These values are reasonably well reproduced by the calculations (0.0, 0.4, and −0.2 ppm for H1′, H2′, and H3′, respectively).

    Activities of CDNs in the Digitonin Reporter Assay

    The activities of the CDNs were determined using the reporter HEK 293T ISRE cell lines prepared in our laboratory.(32) Each cell line expresses one of the five most abundant STING haplotypes found in the human population (wild type (WT) STING, REF STING, AQ STING, Q STING, and HAQ STING),(59) and luciferase as a reporter is expressed in an IRF3-dependent manner upon the interaction of STING with the CDNs.(60) The allelic forms differ in their CDN binding capacities, especially in the cases of REF and Q STING as they have been shown to bind bacterial 3′,3′-CDNs less efficiently.(59,61,62) To assess the ability of the CDNs to stimulate various STING allelic forms, we performed a digitonin assay as described previously.(32,59) As digitonin A permeabilizes cell membranes,(63) allowing an easy uptake of polar CDNs, we were able to measure the CDN–STING interaction in the cell context regardless of the CDN transport through the cell membrane.
    We compared the phosphodiester CDN (1) and bisphosphorothioates (8) together with the monophosphorothioates (12, see the Supporting Information)(43) and known natural bacterial and eukaryotic CDNs (3′,3′-cGAMP, 3′,3′-c-di-AMP, 3′,3′-c-di-GMP, and 2′,3′-cGAMP) and synthetic 2′,2′-cGAMP. As expected, REF EC50 values for bacterial 3′,3′-cGAMP and 3′,3′-c-di-AMP (but not 3′,3′-c-di-GMP) were much higher than those of the other STING allelic forms, whereas the difference in the EC50 value for eukaryotic 2′,3′-cGAMP was much less profound. Q STING EC50 values were much higher for all 3′,3′-CDNs than those in the cases of other STING allelic forms (Table 2). Thus, these data are in agreement with already-published results.(59) REF and Q STING EC50 values for synthetic 2′,2′-cGAMP were also higher, but the difference was smaller those than for 3′,3′-CDNs. The introduction of fluorine to the 2′-position of the ribose improved the activities of 1, (Rp,Sp)-8, (Rp,Rp)-8, (Sp)-12, and (Rp)-12 compared to that of 3′,3′-c-di-AMP (Table 2).(44,64) More importantly, some of the fluorine-modified CDNs bound much more efficiently to the REF and Q STING allelic forms, which are present in about 14% of the human population.(59,61) Nonmodified 3′,3′-c-di-AMP activated REF STING more than 100× less than WT STING, whereas the difference between REF and WT STING was less than 10×in the cases of 1, (Rp,Rp)-8, and (Rp)-12. Interestingly, having the sulfur atom in the α-position (up, (Sp)-configuration) as seen with (Sp,Sp)-8, (Rp,Sp)-8, and (Sp)-12 actually impairs the activity against REF STING by 2–50× compared to that of the parent 3′,3′-c-di(2′F,2′dAMP) (1). Importantly, the thiophosphate CDNs (Rp,Rp)-8 and (Rp)-12 with a sulfur atom in the β-position (down, (Rp)-configuration) show less than a threefold difference in activity across all five tested STING allelic forms, showing profiles similar to that of the natural eukaryotic CDN 2′,3′-cGAMP.
    Table 2. Activities of CDNs in the Digitonin HEK 293T Cell-Based Reporter Assay
     EC50 (μM) (±SEM)a
    compoundWTHAQREFAQQ
    10.02 (±0.006)0.13 (±0.10)0.18 (±0.03)0.05 (±0.008)0.14 (±0.03)
    (Sp,Sp)-80.17 (±0.07)0.88 (±0.26)8.70 (±1.68)0.26 (±0.03)4.07 (±1.78)
    (Rp,Sp)-80.02 (±0.007)0.05 (±0.02)0.36 (±0.12)0.03 (±0.01)0.21 (±0.05)
    (Rp,Rp)-80.04 (±0.01)0.08 (±0.02)0.13 (±0.03)0.04 (±0.009)0.08 (±0.03)
    (Sp)-120.007 (±0.002)0.13 (±0.03)0.92 (±0.22)0.07 (±0.008)0.45 (±0.05)
    (Rp)-120.04 (±0.01)0.10 (±0.005)0.14 (±0.04)0.04 (±0.02)0.10 (±0.05)
    3′,3′-c-di-AMP0.26 (±0.04)0.19 (±0.03)>450.17 (±0.03)7.09 (±0.86)
    3′,3′-c-di-GMP4.47 (±0.78)0.89 (±0.12)8.41 (±1.95)1.05 (±0.13)>45
    3′,3′-cGAMP0.12 (±0.03)0.12 (±0.01)4.26 (±0.49)0.26 (±0.09)2.06 (±0.36)
    2′,2′-cGAMP0.03 (±0.005)0.02 (±0.006)0.21 (±0.04)0.03 (±0.006)0.17 (±0.04)
    2′,3′-cGAMP0.02 (±0.004)0.02 (±0.003)0.07 (±0.02)0.04 (±0.01)0.05 (±0.02)
    a

    Results of the digitonin assay using HEK 293T cells expressing different STING haplotypes and reporter luciferase. EC50 values represent the mean (±SEM) of at least two independent experiments measured in triplicate.

    Structure and Energetic Details of the Binding of 8 and 12 to STING: X-ray Crystallography and Quantum Mechanics/Molecular Mechanics (QM/MM) Calculations

    To understand the effect of the configuration of the phosphorothioate in 8 and 12, we studied the details of their binding to STING by employing X-ray crystallography and QM/MM calculations. We crystallized 3′,3′-c-[2′F,2′dAMP-2′F,2′dAM(PS)] ((Rp)-12) in a complex with WT STING and REF STING (R232H mutation) (Figures 5 and S2). Crystals belonged to the space groups P41212 and P22121, and diffracted to a resolution of 2.5 and 2.3 Å, respectively (Tables S4 and S5). As expected, the R232H mutation resulted in the loss of a polar (ion pair) interaction between the phosphate group of the ligand and the charged side chain of Arg, leading to the different binding mode of the ligand and the lower ligand binding ability of STING (Figure 5C). Other than that, we found that both crystal structures (WT and REF) in the complex with the (Rp)-12 were nearly identical (Figure 5A; R.M.S.D. of Cα carbons is 0.58). Both structures are also in a very good agreement with the structures published by us and others for analogous STING ligands (PDB 4KSY, 6S26, and 6S86), including the conformations of the ligands in the binding site.(9,32,65) The binding of the (Rp)-12 to R232H (REF) STING lacks the water-mediated interaction observed in the WT STING crystal structure between R232 and the phosphate oxygen of (Rp)-12 (Figure 5C). This may qualitatively explain why (Rp)-12 activated the REF STING about four times less efficiently than WT STING in the digitonin reporter assay (Table 2), although the receptor was fully closed. We can also compare the R232H (REF) STING with our recent study(33) in which we reported the activities and structure–/activity correlations of a series of rationally designed STING mutants, including the R232K mutation. Similar to H232, K232 did not interact with the ligand directly even though the protein STING maintained the closed conformation. Thus, we speculate that R232 is not essential for receptor activation yet it may significantly improve the binding of CDNs to STING.
    We also crystallized 3′,3′-c-di[2′F,2′dAM(PS)] ((Rp,Rp)-8) in complex with the WT STING (Figure 5 and S3). The crystal belonged to the space group P41212, and diffracted to the resolution of 3.2 Å (Table S4). The final structure (the crystallographic details are in Table S5) is depicted in Figure 5. Again, the structure did not show any significant difference compared to the other known STING structures. The slightly different position of the nucleobases (Figure 5E and F) in comparison to those in 3′,3′-c-di(2′F,2′dAMP) (1) bound to WT STING (PDB 6Z0Z)(66) is not significant considering the low resolution of the new structure presented. It should be noticed that our crystallographic experiments also independently confirmed the absolute configuration of the phosphorothioate groups of 8 and 12, which were obtained by NMR spectrometry in combination with the DFT calculations (see above) and the QM/MM calculations (see below).
    To further corroborate these findings and provide a more quantitative footing for the experimental observations, a series of QM/MM calculations was carried out for all five isomers of 8 and 12 (the energy minima for the three isomers of 8 are depicted in Figure 4; all other equilibrium structures, including one sample structure of the full protein and all quantum regions of the isomers of 8 and 12, are in the Supporting Information). To test the robustness of the approach, which was successfully used in our previous studies on ligand binding to STING,(32,33) and reflect the minimal asymmetry of the QM/MM models (mostly positions of the water molecules that may not reflect the overall symmetry of the dimeric protein), we calculated eight ligand–protein complexes. Specifically, by considering the two phosphate groups as distinct moieties, we modeled the (Rp)- and (Rs)-configurations on each of them (four complexes for monosubstituted CDNs), both (Rp,Sp) and (Sp,Rp) configurations, and the (Rp,Rp) and (Sp,Sp) configurations—four complexes for disubstituted CDNs. The computed interaction energies and strain energies for each ligand are listed in Table 3.
    Table 3. Computed QM/MM and QM-Only (Cluster) Energies of the 8- and 12-STING Ligand–protein Complexes, Interaction (Free) Energies between 8 and 12 and the STING, and Ligand Strain Energies
    compoundEQM/MMEQM,clusterG′intG′strain,ligandG′int,no_strainDSF WT STING ΔTm (°C, ± SEM)e
    (Sp,-)-120.0a–0.3–2.2c11.8d–0.88.9 (±0.6)f
    (Rp,-)-12–6.4–7.0–10.710.3–3.814.7 (±0.5)g
    (-,Rp)-12–7.7–6.7–9.211.1–7.814.7 (±0.5)g
    (-,Sp)-12–0.30.0–3.59.80.08.9 (±0.6)f
    (Sp,Rp)-8–7.1b–5.9–7.411.3–10.511.2 (±0.9)h
    (Sp,Sp)-80.00.00.012.8–2.65.5 (±0.5)
    (Rp,Rp)-8–14.6–13.4–16.011.0–16.915.9 (±0.3)
    (Rp,Sp)-8–6.4–6.5–8.310.6–7.011.2 (±0.9)h
    a

    All values are in kilocalories per mole.

    b

    Relative QM/MM energies (EQM/MM) and cluster model energies (EQM, the QM system in an implicit solvent) representing the “absolute energetics” can be compared only within the four isomers of 8 and the four isomers of 12.

    c

    Relative interaction free energies, including protein and ligand strain, i.e., computed proxies to thermodynamic binding constants (can be compared across all eight isomers studied).

    d

    The ligand strain energy is defined as the difference between the free energy of its global minimum in solution and the free energy corresponding to the exact (QM/MM) conformation it adopts in the active site.

    e

    Results of a differential scanning fluorimetry (DSF) assay for the WT STING allelic form. ΔTm values represent the mean (±SEM) of two independent experiments measured in triplicate.

    f

    (Sp,-)-12 and (-,Sp)-12 are the compound (Sp)-12 in DSF and cell-based assays, respectively.

    g

    (Rp,-)-12 and (-,Rp)-12 are the compound (Rp)-12 in DSF and cell-based assays, respectively.

    h

    (Sp,Rp)-8 and (Rp,Sp)-8 are the compound (Rp,Sp)-8 in DSF and cell-based assays, respectively.

    As shown in our previous work,(32) the QM/MM energies can correlate with the binding constants obtained by isothermal titration calorimetry or differential scanning fluorimetry. Indeed, the calculations reflect all experimental observations reported here. First, they perfectly agree with the X-ray crystallography data and predict that the (Rp)-12 and (Rp,Rp)-8 isomers are the most energetically stable ligand–protein complexes. The robustness of the QM/MM and QM predictions (energetic data are presented in Table 3) is confirmed not only by the almost identical values (to within ∼1 kcal/mol) obtained for both the full QM/MM model (“absolute” QM/MM energy, EQM/MM) and the conceptually simpler QM-only (cluster) model of the ligand–protein binding site immersed in an implicit solvent (EQM) but also by the minor interaction energy differences (0.7–1.3 kcal/mol) computed for the three symmetric pairs (-,Rp)-12 and (Rp,-)-12, (-,Sp)-12 and (Sp,-)-12, and (Rp,Sp)-12 and (Sp,Rp)-12.
    Most notably, the computed (relative) G′int values, which are our best estimates of the interaction free energies, are in perfect agreement with the experimental DSF values (Table 3) that were previously shown to correlate well with the true thermodynamic constants (ΔGbind and KD).(33) This demonstrates the predictive power of the QM/MM calculations once the initial structures are supported by the crystallographic data. Thus, the data clearly show that the majority of the differences in the binding of 8 and 12, with respect to the (S) or (R)-position of the sulfur, originate in the different interactions of the particular ligand with STING. This is semiquantitatively proven by the almost constant values of the ligand strain energies (Gstrain,ligand = 9.8–12.8 kcal/mol) and by the similar interaction free energy values when the ligand and protein are “locked” in the geometry of the complex (G′int,no_strain).
    In Figure 6, a close-up of the different binding patterns is depicted. As can be seen in Figure 6, the more favorable interaction energies of (Rp)-12 and (Rp,Rp)-8, in comparison to their (Sp)-12 and (Sp,Sp)-8 counterparts, seem to be governed by the loss of the favorable interaction of the (harder) phosphate oxygen with the two Arg moieties of STING. The interaction energy of the softer sulfur with the two positive charges on the Arg moieties is expectedly less favorable, as is quantitatively reflected by the computed interaction energies (Table 3). The magnitude of the difference in energy between the Arg232+···O and S···Arg23B+ interactions can be estimated as 7–8 kcal/mol per one phosphorothioate group (from G′int values in Table 3).

    Activities of CDNs and Prodrugs in Standard HEK 293T and THP1-Dual Reporter Assays

    We measured the activities of the prodrugs and their parent CDNs in HEK 293T WT STING cells and THP1-Dual (Invitrogen) cells in the absence of digitonin A (the so-called standard assay). We determined the EC50 values of the compounds after a 30 min pulse and 7 h of continuous incubation to better understand the effect of their uptake and metabolism (cleavage of the prodrug moiety and the release of the active CDN) on their activity. A smaller shift in the EC50 values was observed between the two different time points, and thus a more efficient uptake of the CDNs and a more efficient metabolism of the prodrugs was anticipated.
    The cell membrane is the main barrier for the delivery of polar CDNs into the cytoplasm, as they require active transport facilitated by the recently described SLC19A1 transporter.(21) Consistently, the EC50 values of the parent CDNs were up to 400× higher in the standard than those in the digitonin assay, confirming that the rate of cellular uptake is the limiting factor in their activities (Table 2 and 4). Interestingly, the activities of the parent CDNs was cell-line-dependent. Compound 1 showed about 5–8× lower EC50 values in the monocyte-derived THP1-Dual cells than in the kidney-derived HEK 293T cells, whereas (Sp,Sp)-8 and (Rp,Sp)-8 were about 6× more active in the HEK 293T cells than in the THP1-Dual cells (Tables 4 and 5, respectively). This points to the possible differences among tissues or cell types that may involve multiple different uptake transport proteins with varying affinities to CDNs and differential expressions in tissues; however, this needs to be further explored.
    Table 4. Activities of CDNs and Prodrugs in a Standard HEK 293T WT STING Cell-Based Reporter Assay
     30 min7 h
    compoundparentEC50 (μM) (±SEM)aEC50 parent/prodrugbEC50 (μM) (±SEM)aEC50 parent/prodrugb

    Table 5. Activities of CDNs and Prodrugs in Standard THP1-Dual Cell-Based Reporter Assays

    3′,3′-cGAMP 58.46 (±20.65)na4.74 (±0.62)na
    a

    Results of the cell-based assay in the THP1-Dual reporter cell line. EC50 values represent the mean (±SEM) of at least three independent experiments measured in triplicate.

    b

    Fold of the EC50 of a parent compound compared to the EC50 of a prodrug derived from that parent; na, nonapplicable.

    On the other hand, the prepared lipophilic prodrugs of 3′,3′-c-di(2′F,2′dAMP) (1) and 3′,3′-c-di-[2′F,2′dAMP(S)] (8) reached EC50 values similar to those of their parents in the digitonin assay after 7 h, thus confirming that the prodrugs freely diffused into the cells (Tables 4 and 5). The metabolism of inactive prodrugs to the active parent CDNs also has to be efficient, as the EC50 values of the prodrugs were up to three orders of magnitude lower than those of the parent and control CDNs after only 30 min of pulse incubation (Tables 4 and 5).
    The activities of the prodrugs were similar in both cell lines, but were also dependent on their polarities. The more polar monoalkylated prodrugs (3a–3d) were less active than their more lipophilic bis-alkylated counterparts (4a–d) (Tables 4 and 5). The symmetric diastereoisomers of bis-alkylated prodrugs in the phosphodiester series ((Rp,Rp)-4a, (Rp,Rp)-4b, and (Rp,Rp)-4d) had EC50 values about 2–3× lower than those of the asymmetric diastereoisomers ((Rp,Sp)-4a, (Rp,Sp)-4b, and (Rp,Sp)-4d), while the Rp,Rp diastereoisomer of the phophorothioate-derived prodrugs (Rp,Rp)-8 was slightly less potent than the (Sp,Sp)-8 or (Sp,Rp)-8 diastereoisomers (Tables 4 and 5).
    The symmetric bis(POC) prodrug ((Rp,Rp)-4d) was at least four times less active than the symmetric ethylbutanoateoxymethyl ((Rp,Rp)-4b) and symmetric bis(POM) ((Rp,Rp)-4a) prodrugs in a 30 min pulse incubation. However, the differences among these prodrugs were much less profound when they were present continuously (7 h) in the cell culture. The symmetric bis(POM) prodrug ((Rp,Rp)-4a) and the bis(POM) phosphorothioate-derived prodrugs (9) had the smallest shifts in their EC50 values during the pulse and the continuous incubation, indicating the most efficient uptake, metabolism, and STING activation of all the prepared prodrugs in both cell lines (Table 4 and 5).
    Finally, at the 7 h time point the EC50 values of the phosphodiester-derived symmetric bis-prodrugs ((Rp,Rp)-4a, (Rp,Rp)-4b, and (Rp,Rp)-4d) and even some asymmetric bis-prodrugs ((Rp,Sp)-4a–4c) and prodrugs 9 derived from phosphorothioate analogues (8) were similar to those of the parent CDNs in the digitonin assay (Tables 2 and 4). This indicates that the digitonin assay predicts EC50 values for the optimized prodrugs of CDNs. We also analyzed the maximum activation signals to compare the magnitude of the STING pathway activation. No significant differences in maximum activation signals were present among prodrugs, parent CDNs, and control CDNs in either cell line (data not shown).

    Induction of Cytokine Production by CDNs and Their Prodrugs in Peripheral Blood Mononuclear Cells

    The activation of the cGAS-STING pathway leads to the induction of cytokine and chemokine expression.(1,16,17,60) Therefore, to compare the observed CDN-associated effect in the reporter cell lines with a more biologically relevant model, we measured the proinflammatory cytokine production by peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMC) isolated from the buffy coats of healthy human donors. We determined the EC50 values of interferon-α (IFNα), interferon-γ (IFNγ), and tumor necrosis factor-α (TNFα) production stimulated by the tested compounds for 16 h. The monoprodrugs were not included in the testing because of their consistently lower activity in reporter cell-based assays.
    Various observations from the reporter cell-based assays can be translated into the heterogeneous population of PBMC, e.g., a significant improvement of the prodrug activity over that of the parent CDNs or a superior potency of the symmetric phosphodiester prodrugs compared to the asymmetric ones (Table 6). Similar to the reporter cell-based assays, the ethylbutanoateoxymethyl prodrug ((Rp,Rp)-4b) was the most potent, followed by the bis(POM) ((Rp,Rp)-4a) prodrug, the benzoyloxymethyl (Rp,Sp)-4c prodrug, and the bis(POC) prodrug ((Rp,Rp)-4d) (Table 6). Consistent with the reporter cell-based assays, the EC50 values of parent phosphodiesters and phosphorothioates were at least six times higher than those of the prodrugs for all three measured cytokines, confirming that the prodrugs are superior to the parent CDNs even in physiologically more relevant cell populations. In the case of the most potent prodrug (Rp,Rp)-4b, the difference was more than 900×.
    Table 6. Activities of CDNs and Prodrugs in Human PBMC
     INFαIFNγTNFα
    compoundEC50 (μM) (±SEM)aEC50 parent/prodrugbEC50 (μM) (±SEM)aEC50 parent/prodrugbEC50 (μM) (±SEM)aEC50 parent/prodrugb
    150.96 (±18.98)na8.23 (±4.88)na12.78 (±5.07)na
    (Rp,Sp)-4a0.44 (±0.10)1150.07 (±0.03)1100.24 (±0.09)133
    (Rp,Rp)-4a0.22 (±0.05)2340.06 (±0.02)1480.11 (±0.04)279

    a

    Results of the cell-based assay in human PBMC isolated from the buffy coats of healthy donors. EC50 values represent the mean (±SEM) of at least three independent experiments measured in triplicate.

    b

    Fold of the EC50 of a parent compound compared to the EC50 of a prodrug derived from that parent; na, nonapplicable.

    Additionally, we analyzed the maximum cytokine concentrations to determine any differences in the cytokine production. No significant differences in the maximum IFNα, IFNγ, or TNFα production were present among the prodrugs, parent CDNs, and control CDNs (data not shown).

    Uptake, Efflux, and Metabolism of Prodrugs

    To determine the uptake, efflux, and metabolism of the prodrugs, 3H-radiolabeled POM prodrugs and parent CDNs were prepared. Prodrugs [3H]-(Rp,Sp)-4a and [3H]-(Rp,Rp)-4a entered THP1-Dual cells rapidly and were efficiently metabolized to the only detectable intracellular metabolite [3H]-1 (parent 3′,3′-c-di(2′F,2′dAMP)) as determined by HPLC-LS analysis. Intracellular levels of [3H]-1 peaked in 2 h but then decreased (Figure 7A). This rapid metabolism is consistent with the small shift in the EC50 values for both prodrugs at the pulse and continuous incubation in THP1-Dual cells (Table 4). This could be advantageous, in particular in the case of their intratumoral application as the potential redistribution of prodrugs to other tissues may be unwanted. The more potent prodrug [3H]-(Rp,Rp)-4a delivered a higher intracellular concentration of the parent CDN than [3H]-(Rp,Sp)-4a, confirming its superiority observed in the reporter THP1-Dual assay (Table 4). The intracellular levels of [3H]-1 were not detectable when THP1-Dual cells were treated with [3H]-1 at the same extracellular concentration that was used in the case of prodrugs. However, we were able to detect [3H]-1 in cells when a 100× higher concentration was used. Contrary to the rapid entry of the prodrugs, the parent CDN was barely detectable in cells after a 2 h incubation, and its intracellular concentration increased linearly for up to 24 h (Figure 7A). These observations confirm the results from reporter cell-based assays that showed a major difference between the EC50 values after 30 min and those after 7 h of incubation with parent CDNs, further supporting the claim of the free diffusion entry of prodrugs into cells as opposed to the transporter-mediated entry of the parent CDNs.
    To ascertain the decrease of the intracellular concentration of [3H]-1 after a 2 h incubation with prodrugs, we looked at the efflux of [3H]-1 from cells. The cells were incubated for 2 h with the most potent prodrug [3H]-(Rp,Rp)-4a to achieve the maximum intracellular concentration of [3H]-1. They were then washed extensively to remove the leftover prodrug before being incubated in a fresh medium. As shown in Figure 7B, the intracellular concentration of [3H]-1 rapidly decreased with a half-time of 90 min. Even though the identity of the transporters involved in the export of CDNs from cells is unknown so far, the transfer of 2′,3′-cGAMP from infected or damaged cells to surrounding cells is important for signaling and results in the protection of the surrounding unaffected cells or triggers innate and adaptive immune responses.(67,68)
    Prodrugs (Rp,Sp)-4a and (Rp,Rp)-4a were also evaluated for stability in mouse and human plasma. They had moderate stabilities in human plasma (T1/2 of 60 and 70 min, respectively), but were highly unstable in mouse plasma (T1/2 < 2 min), thus precluding their study in mouse tumor models.

    Conclusions

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    In this study, we describe for the first time the synthesis of the phosphoester prodrugs of CDNs. The developed methodology is based on the alkylation of the tetrabutylammonium salt of CDNs and can be universally applied.(69−71) Furthermore, we prepared a series of bis(acyloxymethyl) and bis(POC) prodrugs of 1 and bis(POM) prodrugs of its phosphorothioate counterpart 8 and performed a structure–activity relationship study with these compounds. We show the overall superior activity of the prodrugs relative to their parent CDNs in two different reporter cell lines as well as PBMC. We determined the absolute configurations of the CDNs by NMR spectrometry and DFT calculations and confirmed them by crystallography. In addition, the QM/MM calculations provided not only show an excellent agreement with the experimental data (both structural and ligand binding) but also show clear structure–activity correlations and details of the protein–ligand interaction. Last but not least, we show that the uptake and intracellular metabolism of bis(POM) prodrugs is rapid and efficient. By comparing the behaviors of multiple prodrugs in reporter cell lines and PBMC, we selected the symmetric bis(POM) prodrug (Rp,Rp)-4a to be the best candidate for further studies of its anticancer therapeutic potential, especially for an intratumoral application. First, its parent CDN efficiently interacts with all the most abundant allelic forms of STING present in humans. Second, its uptake is fast, and the prodrug moieties are cleaved rapidly in cells. Third, the difference between the EC50 values of the parent and the prodrug is substantial in reporter cell lines as well as PBMC. Fourth, the pivaloyloxymethyl prodrug moiety is already present in compounds successfully used as antivirotics in human medicine.(23) The prodrug (Rp,Rp)-4a could also be further explored as an antiviral agent.

    Experimental Section

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Unless otherwise stated, solvents were evaporated at 40 °C at 2 kPa, and prepared compounds were dried at 30 °C at 2 kPa. Starting compounds and reagents were purchased from commercial suppliers (Sigma-Aldrich, Fluorochem, Acros Organics, Carbosynth, and TCI) and used without further purification. Dry tetrahydrofuran was distilled with lithium aluminum hydride pellets under argon. Diethyl ether, dioxane, dimethylformamide, and acetonitrile were dried using a Pure Solv system (Innovative Technology, Inc.). Other dry solvents were purchased from commercial suppliers (Sigma-Aldrich and Acros Organics). Analytical TLC was performed on silica gel-precoated aluminum plates with a fluorescent indicator (Merck 60 F254). Flash column chromatography was carried out by a Teledyne ISCO CombiFlash Rf200 system with a dual absorbance detector. Various types of columns were used: (a) Teledyne ISCO RediSepRf HP Silica GOLD columns in sizes 12, 40, 80, and 120 g; (b) Teledyne ISCO RediSepRf HP C18 Aq GOLD columns in sizes 50 and 100 g; (c) Chromabond Flash DL 40, DL 80, DL 120, and DL 200 columns filled with Fluka silica gel 60; and (d) Interchim puriFlash C18 Aq columns in sizes F0040 and F0080. Mass spectra, UV absorbency, and compound purity were recorded and measured on a Waters UPLC-MS system that consisted of a Waters UPLC H-Class core system (Waters Acquity UPLC BEH C18 column, 1.7 mm, 2.1 × 100 mm), a Waters Acquity UPLC PDA detector, and a Waters SQD2 mass spectrometer. The universal LC method was used (H2O/CH3CN eluent, 0–100% gradient, and a run length 7 min) in addition to the MS method (ESI+ or ESI–, cone voltage of 30 V, and mass detector range of 100–1000 Da in the standard case or 500–1600 Da for larger molecules). High-resolution mass spectra were recorded on an LTQ Orbitrap XL spectrometer (Thermo Fisher Scientific). NMR spectra were obtained using a Bruker Avance III HD 500 MHz spectrometer operating at 125.7 MHz for 13C and 500 MHz for 1H. The spectra were referenced to either solvent residual signals (DMSO, 2.50 for 1H and 39.70 for 13C) or tert-butyl alcohol, which was used as an internal standard in D2O solutions (δ 1.24 and 30.29 ppm for 1H and 13C, respectively). The assignment of hydrogen and carbon spectra was based on a combination of 1D and 2D experiments (1H, 13C-APT, 1H,1H–-COSY, 1H,13C-HSQC, and 1H,13C-HMBC).
    The concentration of CDNs was measured using an Implen NanoPhotometer N60 Touch system. Preparative HPLC purifications were performed on a Waters Delta 600 chromatography system with columns packed with C18 reversed phase resin (XterraPrep RP18 column, 5 μM, 10 × 100 mm) using a linear gradient of either H2O/ACN (for prodrugs) or 0.1 M TEAB in water to 0.1 M TEAB in 50% aq. ACN (for free CDNs) as eluents. The purities of the final compounds were determined by UPLC MS and were 95% or higher.
    Laboratory equipment used for the synthesis of [3H]-labeled compounds are as follows: glovebox with a Tritiation manifold from RC-TRITEC AG (Teufen, Switzerland) suitable for handling up to 1000 Ci of carrier-free tritium gas, analytical-preparative radio-HPLC system (Waters Alliance 2695 instrument; PDA detector 2998; flow radioactivity detector Ramona with an analytical cell (LSC) and a solid scintillator preparative cell (Raytest, Germany); Empower 3 data management software; and a Gemini RP18 column, 5 μM, 250 × 10 mm), a PerkinElmer Tri-Carb 2900TR liquid scintillation spectrometer, and a LABCONCO CentiVap ultralow cold trap. The mass spectra were obtained in the ESI mode on either a Q-Tof micro (Waters) or an LTQ Orbitrap XL (Thermo Fisher Scientific for the HR-MS spectra) system. 3′,3′-c-Di(2′F,2′dAMP) (1) was either purchased from a commercial supplier or prepared according to the literature.(31)

    General Procedure for the Synthesis of Prodrugs (GP1)

    CDN (1 μMol, Et3NH+ salt) in dry MeOH (1000 μL) was treated with Bu4N+OH– (2 μMol, 1 M solution in MeOH, 2 μL) at rt, and the mixture was stirred for 30 min. The solvent was removed under reduced pressure, and the residue was dried via codistillation with dry toluene (1 × 500 μL) and dry ACN (2 × 500 μL). The residue in dry ACN (700 μL) was treated with an appropriate alkylation agent (10 μMol) under an argon atmosphere at rt for 3–9 h. The reaction mixture was quenched with 1 mL of 50% H2O/ACN, further diluted with 3 mL of water, and directly applied to the HPLC column. The fractions containing the product were freeze-dried, and the crude product was repurified using HPLC. The fractions containing the product were freeze-dried to give a white solid.

    Compounds (Rp)-3a, (Rp,Sp)-4a, and (Rp,Rp)-4a

    GP1 was used, and CDN was alkylated using POM-I (2a) (2.27 μL) for 9 h.

    (Rp)-Mono(POM) Prodrug of 3′,3′-c-Di(2′F,2′dAMP) ((Rp)-3a)

    Yield: 12%. 1H NMR (DMSO-d6): δ 8.35 and 8.16 (s, 1H, 8); 8.10 and 8.08 (s, 1H, 2); 7.37 (bs, 4H, NH2); 6.33 (dd, J(1′, F) = 19.2 Hz, J(1′, 2′) = 2.3 Hz, 1H, 1′); 6.29 (d, J(1′, F) = 18.4, 1H, 1′); 5.37–5.73 (m, 5H, 2′, 3′, OCH2O); 4.82 (m, 1H, 3′); 4.42 (d, Jgem = 11.6 Hz, 1H, 5′); 4.25–4.31 (m, 2H, 4′); 4.20 (m, 1H, 5′); 4.03 and 3.86 (d, Jgem = 12.1 Hz, 1H, 5′); 1.15 (s, 9H, CH3) ppm. 31P NMR (DMSO-d6): δ −1.50 (bs); −2.90 (s) ppm. 19F NMR (DMSO-d6): δ −196.02 (dt, J(F, 2′) = 47.1 Hz, J(F, 1′) = J(F, 3′) = 21.2 Hz); −197.44 (dm, J(F, 2′) = 51.7 Hz) ppm.     Yield: 11%. 1H NMR (DMSO-d6): δ 8.32 (s, 2H, 8); 8.18 (s, 2H, 2); 7.43 (bs, 4H, NH2); 6.43 (dd, J(1′, F) = 20.2 Hz, J(1′, 2′) = 1.6 Hz, 2H, 1′); 5.77–5.89 (m, 4H, 2′, 3′); 5.62–5.68 (m, 4H, OCH2O); 4.81 (septet, J(CH, CH3) = 6.3 Hz, 2H, CH–iPr); 4.30–4.43 (m, 6H, 4′, 5′); 1.21 (d, J(CH3, CH) = 6.3 Hz, 6H, CH3–iPr); 1.21 (d, J(CH3, CH) = 6.3 Hz, 6H, CH3–iPpr) ppm. 31P NMR (DMSO-d6): δ −3.23 (s) ppm. 19F NMR (DMSO-d6): δ −196.37 (dt, J(F, 2′) = 52.1 Hz, J(F, 1′) = J(F, 3′) = 19.2 Hz) ppm.
