    Phosphorothioates (Sp,Sp)-8, (Rp,Sp)-8, and (Rp,Rp)-8

    H-phosphonate (6) (1 g, 2.27 mmol) was codistilled with dry DMF (5 mL), carefully suspended in dry DCM (35 mL), and stirred under argon over 3 Å molecular sieves overnight. Phosphoramidite (5) (2.2 g, 2.52 mmol) was codistilled with dry DMF (5 mL), carefully suspended in dry DCM (35 mL), and stirred under argon over 3 Å molecular sieves overnight. 5-(Ethylthio)-1H-tetrazole (ETT, 1.63 g, 12.52 mmol) in dry DCM (20 mL) was stirred under argon over 3 Å molecular sieves overnight. Suspensions of 6 and 5 were mixed under an argon atmosphere, the solution of ETT was slowly added, and the resulting mixture was stirred under argon for 4 h. The mixture was then treated with 3-((dimethylaminomethylidene)amino)-3H-1,2,4-dithizole-3-thione (0.514 g, 2.5 mmol) and stirred for 1 h. To the mixture was added 300 μL of water, followed by 2,2-dichloroacetic acid (1.2 mL in 10 mL of DCM), and the mixture was stirred for 15 min. The resulting mixture was treated with triethylsilane (5 mL) for 1 h, then pyridine (10 mL) was added. The mixture was filtered, solids were washed with pyridine (10 mL) and MeOH (2 × 20 mL), and the filtrate was evaporated. The crude product was purified by flash chromatography (reverse phase, eluted with a linear gradient from 0.01 M NH4CO3 to ACN) to give a white solid (750 mg, 35%) of the linear dimer 7. MS (ESI): m/z 942.8 [M + H]+.
    The linear dimer 7 (100 mg, 0.106 mmol) was codistilled with dry pyridine (3 × 5 mL) and dissolved in dry pyridine (10 mL). Then, 2-chloro-5,5-dimethyl-1,3,2-dioxaphosphinane 2-oxide (98 mg, 0.53 mmol) was added in one portion. The mixture was stirred for 3 h at rt, then sulfur (17 mg, 0.53 mmol) was added. The resulting mixture was stirred for 1 h at rt and then quenched with water (500 μL). The resulting suspension was diluted with MeOH (10 mL), filtered, and washed with MeOH (2 × 10 mL) and ACN (2 × 10 mL), and the filtrate was evaporated. The crude product was treated with MeNH2 (4 mL, 33% solution in EtOH) for 1 h. The volatiles were evaporated, and the crude mixture was purified by preparative reverse phase HPLC (eluted with a linear gradient from 0.1 M TEAB in water to 0.1 M TEAB in ACN). Products containing fractions were evaporated and codistilled with MeOH (3 × 5 mL), and the products were freeze-dried from water.

    (Sp,Sp)-3′,3′-c-Di[2′F,2′dAMP(S)] ((Sp,Sp)-8)

    Yield: 4 mg (5%), white foam. 1H NMR (D2O): δ 8.50 (s, 1H, 8); 8.11 (s, 1H, 2); 6.43 (d, J(1′, F) = 16.0 Hz, 1H, 1′); 5.88 (dd, J(2′, F) = 51.2 Hz, J(2′, 3′) = 3.8 Hz, 1H, 2′); 5.01 (m, 1H, 3′); 4.58 (bd, J = 9.4 Hz, 1H, 4′); 4.50 (bd, J = 12.4 Hz, 1H, 5′a); 4.14 (dd, J = 11.9 Hz, J = 4.3 Hz, 1H, 5′b) ppm. 13C NMR (D2O): δ 155.66 (6); 153.03 (2); 148.32 (4); 140.36 (8); 119.38 (5); 92.32 (d, J(2′, F) = 188.7 Hz, 2′); 88.31 (d, J(1′, F) = 33.7 Hz, 1′); 80.18 (t, J = 10.4 Hz, 4′); 70.49 (dd, J(3′, F) = 16.1 Hz, J(3′, P) = 7.8 Hz, 3′); 62.08 (d, J(5′, P) = 7.7 Hz, 5′) ppm. 31P NMR (D2O): δ 57.02 (s) ppm. 19F NMR (DMSO-d6): δ −202.36 (ddd, J(F, 2′) = 51.2 Hz, J(F, 3′) = 24.1 Hz, J(F, 1′) = 16.0 Hz) ppm. MS (ESI): m/z 695.0 [M + H]+. HRMS (ESI): m/z calculated for C20H21O8N10F2P2S2 693.04340, found 693.04315.

    (Rp,Sp)-3′,3′-c-Di[2′F,2′dAMP(S)] ((Rp,Sp)-8)

    Yield: 31 mg (42%), white foam. 1H NMR (D2O): δ 8.34 and 8.23 (2 × s, 1H, 8); 8.10 and 7.92 (2 × s, 1H, 2); 6.33 (d, J(1′, F) = 15.7 Hz, 1H) and 6.28 (d, J(1′, F) = 15.4 Hz, 1H, 1′); 6.00 (dd, J(2′, F) = 50.6 Hz, J(2′, 3′) = 3.8 Hz, 1H) and 5.61 (dd, J(2′, F) = 51.3 Hz, J(2′, 3′) = 3.8 Hz, 1H, 2′); 4.95–5.19 (m, 2H, 3′); 4.50–4.63 (m, 3H, 4′, 5′a); 4.15 (dd, J = 11.8 Hz, J = 5.1 Hz, 1H) and 4.08 (dd, J = 11.7 Hz, J = 5.4 Hz, 1H, 5′b) ppm. 13C NMR (D2O): δ 155.34 and 155.24 (6); 153.33 and 152.85 (2); 147.56 and 147.53 (4); 139.83 and 139.51 (8); 118.89 and 118.86 (5); 92.79 (d, J(2′, F) = 188.9 Hz) and 91.76 (d, J(2′, F) = 189.3 Hz, 2′); 88.92 (d, J(1′, F) = 33.7 Hz) and 88.73 (d, J(1′, F) = 33.5 Hz, 1′); 80.73 (m, 4′); 70.86 (dd, J(3′, F) = 15.7 Hz, J(3′, P) = 4.8 Hz) and 69.78 (dd, J(3′, F) = 16.3 Hz, J(3′, P) = 7.7 Hz, 3′); 64.14 (d, J(5′, P) = 4.3 Hz, 5′) and 62.15 (d, J(5′, P) = 8.0 Hz, 5′) ppm. 31P NMR (D2O): δ 56.97 (s), 56.63 (s) ppm. 19F NMR (DMSO-d6): δ −202.05 (ddd, J(F, 2′) = 51.2 Hz, J(F, 3′) = 23.9 Hz, J(F, 1′) = 15.4 Hz); −202.40 (ddd, J(F, 2′) = 50.9 Hz, J(F, 3′) = 23.8 Hz, J(F, 1′) = 15.7 Hz) ppm. MS (ESI): m/z 695.0 [M + H]+. HRMS (ESI): m/z calculated for C20H21O8N10F2P2S2 693.04340, found 693.04322.

    (Rp,Rp)-3′,3′-c-Di[2′F,2′dAMP(S)] ((Rp,Rp)-8)

    Yield: 23 mg (31%), white foam. 1H NMR (D2O): δ 8.15 (s, 1H, 8); 7.90 (s, 1H, 2); 6.22 (d, J(1′, F) = 15.2 Hz, 1H, 1′); 5.67 (dd, J(2′, F) = 50.8 Hz, J(2′, 3′) = 3.9 Hz, 1H, 2′); 5.24 (m, 1H, 3′); 4.59 (m, 2H, 4′, 5′a); 4.06 (dd, Jgem = 12.2 Hz, J(5′b, 4′) = 6.7 Hz, 1H, 5′b) ppm. 13C NMR (D2O): δ 154.90 (6); 152.91 (2); 146.92 (4); 139.53 (8); 118.60 (5); 92.40 (d, J(2′, F) = 188.9 Hz, 2′); 89.49 (d, J(1′, F) = 33.8 Hz, 1′); 81.52 (t, J = 11.2 Hz, 4′); 70.35 (dd, J(3′, F) = 16.2 Hz, J(3′, P) = 8.7 Hz, 3′); 64.27 (d, J(5′, P) = 4.3 Hz, 5′) ppm. 31P NMR (D2O): δ 56.90 (s) ppm. 19F NMR (DMSO-d6): δ −202.29 (ddd, J(F, 2′) = 50.7 Hz, J(F, 3′) = 23.8 Hz, J(F, 1′) = 15.1 Hz) ppm. MS (ESI): m/z 695.0 [M + H]+. HRMS (ESI): m/z calculated for C20H21O8N10F2P2S2 693.04340, found 693.04300.

    Bis(POM) Prodrug of (Sp,Sp)-3′,3′-c-Di[2′F,2′dAMP(S)]((Sp,Sp)-9)

    (Sp,Sp)-8 (Et3NH+ salt, 1 mg, 1.1 μmol) in 50% aqueous ACN (400 μL) was treated with 2a (2.4 μL, 10 μmol) at rt for 4 h. The mixture was diluted with water (4 mL) and directly applied to the preparative reverse phase HPLC (H2O/ACN 0–100%). The product was evaporated. Yield: 530 nmol (48%), white foam. 1H NMR (DMSO-d6): δ 8.32 (s, 2H, 8); 8.17 (s, 2H, 2); 7.42 (bs, 4H, NH2); 6.43 (dd, J(1′, F) = 19.1 Hz, J(1′, 2′) = 2.9 Hz, 2H, 1′); 6.06 (ddd, J(2′, F) = 51.3 Hz, J(2′, 3′) = 4.9 Hz, J(2′, 1′) = 3.0 Hz, 2H, 2′); 5.96 (m, 2H, 3′); 5.11–5.21 (m, 4H, SCH2); 4.63 (m, 2H, 4′); 4.49–4.52 (m, 4H, 5′); 1.05 (s, 18H, CH3) ppm. 31P NMR (DMSO-d6): δ 25.78 (s) ppm. 19F NMR (DMSO-d6): δ −199.66 (dt, J(F, 2′) = 51.6 Hz, J(F, 1′) = J(F, 3′) = 17.4 Hz) ppm. MS (ESI): m/z 923.2 [M + H]+. HRMS (ESI): m/z calculated for C32H43O12N10F2P2S2 923.19411, found 923.19449.

    Bis(POM) Prodrug of (Rp,Sp)-3′,3′-c-Di[2′F,2′dAMP(S)] ((Rp,Sp)-9)

    (Rp,Sp)-8 (Et3NH+ salt, 1 mg, 1.1 μmol) in 50% aqueous ACN (400 μL) was treated with 2a (2.4 μL, 10 μmol) at rt for 4 h. The mixture was diluted with water (4 mL) and directly applied to the preparative reverse phase HPLC (H2O/ACN 0–100%). The product was evaporated. Yield: 670 nmol (61%), white foam. 1H NMR (DMSO-d6): δ 8.37 and 8.32 (2 × s, 1H, 8); 8.18 and 8.17 (s, 2H, 2); 7.43 (bs, 4H, NH2); 6.40–6.47 (m, 2H, 1′); 6.09–6.23 (m, 2H, 2′a, 3′a); 5.77–5.89 (m, 2H, 2′b, 3′b); 5.26–5.46 (m, 4H, SCH2); 4.65 (m, 1H, 4′a); 4.52 (m, 1H, 4′b); 4.25–4.48 (m, 4H, 5′); 1.08 and 1.03 (s, 9H, CH3) ppm. 31P NMR (DMSO-d6): δ 27.42 (s); 25.97 (s) ppm. 19F NMR (DMSO-d6): δ −195.99 (dt, J(F, 2′) = 51.8 Hz, J(F, 1′) = J(F, 3′) = 19.4 Hz); −203.91 (dm, J(F, 2′) = 50.6 Hz) ppm. MS (ESI): m/z 923.2 [M + H]+. HRMS (ESI): m/z calculated for C32H43O12N10F2P2S2 923.19411, found 923.19467.

    Bis(POM) Prodrug of (Rp,Rp)-3′,3′-c-Di[2′F,2′dAMP(S)] ((Rp,Rp)-9)

    (Rp,Rp)-8 (Et3NH+ salt, 1 mg, 1.1 μmol) in 50% aqueous ACN (400 μL) was treated with 2a (2.4 μL, 10 μmol) at rt for 4 h. The mixture was diluted with water (4 mL) and directly applied to the preparative reverse phase HPLC (H2O/ACN 0–100%). The product was evaporated. Yield: 620 nmol (56%), white foam. Purity: 92%. 1H NMR (DMSO-d6): δ 8.35 (s, 2H, 8); 8.18 (s, 2H, 2); 7.42 (bs, 4H, NH2); 6.43 (dd, J(1′, F) = 18.8 Hz, J(1′,2′) = 2.6 Hz, 2H, 1′); 6.03 (m, 2H, 3′); 5.92 (ddd, J(2′, F) = 51.2 Hz, J(2′, 1′) = 2.6 Hz, J(2′, 3′) = 5.0 Hz, 2′); 5.40–5.50 (m, 4H, SCH2); 4.45–4.50 (m, 4H, 4′, 5′a); 4.31 (m, 2H, 5′b); 1.09 (s, 18H, CH3) ppm. 31P NMR (DMSO-d6): δ 28.04 (s) ppm. 19F NMR (DMSO-d6): δ −197.79 (dt, J(F, 2′) = 51.3 Hz, J(F, 1′) = J(F, 3′) = 17.1 Hz) ppm. MS (ESI): m/z 923.2 [M + H]+. HRMS (ESI): m/z calculated for C32H42O12N10F2NaP2S2 945.17606, found 945.17664.

    3′,3′-c-Di(8-Br,2′F,2′dAMP) (10)

    c-Di(2′F,2′dAMP) (1) (6.6 mg, 10 μmol) in a sodium acetate buffer (1 M, pH 4.0, 300 μL) was treated with liquid bromine (3 μL) at rt for 2 h. Upon the completion of the reaction, the excess bromine was quenched by the addition of cyclohexene (1 mL). The resulting mixture was stirred for 1 h, then the cyclohexene was separated and removed. The residue was neutralized with the addition of 2 M TEAB at 0 °C, diluted with water (4 mL), and directly applied to the preparative reverse phase HPLC (eluted with a linear gradient from 0.1 M TEAB in water to 0.1 M TEAB in 50% aqueous ACN). The product-containing fractions were evaporated, codistilled with MeOH (3 × 5 mL), and freeze-dried from water to give 10. Yield: 6 μmol (60%), white foam. 1H NMR (D2O): δ 8.27 (s, 1H, 2); 6.43 (dd, J(1′, F) = 24.8, J(1′, 2′) = 1.7 Hz, 1H, 1′); 6.00 (ddd, J(2′, F) = 52.7 Hz, J(2′, 3′) = 5.7 Hz, J(2′, 1′) = 1.7 Hz, 1H, 2′); 5.50 (dddd, J(3′, F) = 24.8 Hz, J(3′, P) = 7.6 Hz, J(3′, 4′) = 9.1 Hz, J(3′, 2′) = 5.7 Hz, 1H, 3′); 4.36 (dq, J(4′, 3′) = 9.1 Hz, J(4′, 5′a) = 2.5 Hz, J(4′, 5′b) = 1.8 Hz, J(4′, P) = 2.2 Hz, 1H, 4′); 4.30 (bdd, J(5′a, 4′) = 2.5 Hz, J(5′a, 5′b) = 12.4 Hz, J(5′a, P) < 1 Hz, 1H, 5′a); 4.17 (ddd, J(5′b, 4′) = 1.8 Hz, J(5′b, 5′a) = 12.4 Hz, J(5′b, P) = 4.9 Hz, 1H, 5′b) ppm. 31P NMR (D2O): δ −0.75 (s) ppm. 19F NMR (D2O): δ −192.36 (m) ppm. 13C NMR (D2O): δ 157.11 (6); 156.04 (2); 153.09 (4); 130.54 (8); 121.89 (5); 93.61 (d, J(2′, F) = 188.3 Hz, 2′); 91.07 (d, J(1′, F) = 38.7 Hz, 1′); 81.89 (dd, J(4′, F) = J(4′, P) = 10.9 Hz, 4′); 71.84 (dd, J(3′, F) = 15.8 Hz, J(3′, P) = 5.6 Hz, 3′); 64.46 (dd, J(5′, F) = 4.4 Hz, J(5′, P) = 1.8 Hz, 5′) ppm. MS (ESI): m/z 821 [M + H]+.

    Compounds (Sp,Sp)-11, (Rp,Sp)-11, and (Rp,Rp)-11

    GP1 was used, and samples were prepared from 10 and POM-I (2a) at rt for 90 min.

    (Sp,Sp)-Bis(POM) Prodrug of 3′,3′-c-Di(8-Br,2′F,2′dAMP) ((Sp,Sp)-11)

    Yield: 15%. 1H NMR (DMSO-d6): δ 8.33 (s, 2H, 2); 6.21 (dd, J(1′, F) = 23.9 Hz, J(1′, 2′) = 1.4 Hz, 2H, 1′); 6.12 (bs, 4H, NH2); 5.91–6.05 (m, 2H, 2′, 3′); 5.32 (dd, Jgem = 5.2 Hz, J(H, P) = 15.7, 2H, O–CHa–O); 5.26 (dd, Jgem = 5.2 Hz, J(H, P) = 10.7, 2H, O–CHb–O); 4.39–4.48 (m, 6H, 4′, 5′); 1.01 (s, 18H, CH3) ppm. 31P NMR (DMSO-d6): δ −4.96 (s) ppm. 19F NMR (DMSO-d6): δ −193.57 (m) ppm. MS (ESI): m/z 1047.4 [M + H]+. HRMS (ESI): m/z calculated for C32H41O14N10Br2F2P2 1047.06083, found 1047.06154.

    (Rp,Sp)-Bis(POM) Prodrug of 3′,3′-di-c(8-Br,2′F,2′dAMP) ((Rp,Sp)-11)

    Yield: 25%. 1H NMR (DMSO-d6): δ 8.34 and 8.31 (2 × s, 1H, 2); 6.18–6.26 (m, 6H, 1′, NH2); 5.89–6.13 (m, 4H, 2′, 3′); 5.45–5.61 (m, 4H, OCH2O); 4.23–4.45 (m, 6H, 4′, 5′); 1.14 (s, 9H, CH3); 1.00 (s, 9H, CH3) ppm. 31P NMR (DMSO-d6): δ −3.46 (bs); −4.60 (s) ppm. 19F NMR (DMSO-d6): δ −192.37 (m); −194.43 (dt, J(F, 2′) = 51.2 Hz, J(F, 1′) = J(F, 3′) = 20.9 Hz) ppm. MS (ESI): m/z 1047.1 [M + H]+. HRMS (ESI): m/z calculated for C32H41O14N10Br2F2P2 1047.06083, found 1047.06165.

    (Rp,Rp)-Bis(POM) Prodrug of 3′,3′-c-Di(8-Br,2′F,2′dAMP) ((Rp,Rp)-11)

    Yield: 7%. 1H NMR (DMSO-d6): δ 8.37 (s, 2H, 2); 6.24 (dd, J(1′, P) = 23.9 Hz, J(1′, 2′) = 0.9 Hz, 2H, 1′); 6.08–6.16 (m, 6H, 3′, NH2); 5.99 (dd, 2H, J(2′, F) = 52.2 Hz, J(2′, 3′) = 5.1 Hz, 2H, 2′); 5.57–5.63 (m, 4H, OCH2O); 4.39 (m, 2H, 4′); 4.26–4.34 (m, 4H, 5′); 1.15 (s, 18H, CH3) ppm. 31P NMR (DMSO-d6): δ −2.98 (s) ppm. 19F NMR (DMSO-d6): δ −192.59 (ddd, J(F, 2′) = 52.4 Hz, J(F, 1′) = 28.3 Hz, J(F, 3′) = 19.6 Hz) ppm. MS (ESI): m/z 1047.3 [M + H]+. HRMS (ESI): m/z calculated for C32H41O14N10Br2F2P2 1047.06083, found 1047.06154.

    3′,3′-c-Di[8-[3H],2′F,2′dAMP] ([3H]-1)

    The synthetic precursor 10 (1 mg, 1.2 μmol), PdO (1.3 mg), PBS (500 μL, pH 7.6), and EtOH (500 μL) were placed in a round-bottomed flask (2 mL). The flask was mounted on a tritium manifold that was placed in a glovebox, and the reaction mixture was degassed by three successive freeze–thaw cycles (liquid nitrogen and a turbopump vacuum). Carrier-free 3H2 (580 mbar, 4.4 Ci, 164 GBq) trapped on a uranium bed (as uranium tritide) was released by heating (500 °C) and directed into the reaction vial using a tritium manifold. After 3 h of vigorous stirring, the mixture was cooled by liquid nitrogen, and the tritium gas was back-trapped on the waste and tritium U bed. The reaction mixture was filtered through a 0.45 μm polytetrafluorethylene (PTFE) syringe filter, and the tritiation flask and filter were washed by four portions of EtOH (1 mL). Labile activity was removed by the lyophilization of CH3OH/H2O (50:50) (3 × 4 mL) added to the reaction mixture. Analytical HPLC showed a full conversion of the starting material, and preparative HPLC gave 36.7 mCi of pure [3H]-1. The specific activity of [3H]-1 was determined by ESI-HRMS (profile mode) at 37.7 Ci/mmol. HRMS (ESI): m/z calculated for C20H21T2F2N10O10P2 667.12069, found 667.12415.

    (Sp,Sp)-Bis(POM) Prodrug of 3′,3′-c-Di[8-[3H],2′F,2′dAMP] ([3H]-(Sp,Sp)-4a)

    The synthetic precursor (Sp,Sp)-11 (1 mg, 0.9 μmol), PdO (1.5 mg), PBS (500 μL, pH 7.6), and EtOH (500 μL) were placed in a round-bottomed flask (2 mL). The flask was mounted on a tritium manifold that was placed in a glovebox, and the reaction mixture was degassed by three successive freeze–thaw cycles (liquid nitrogen and a turbopump vacuum). Carrier-free 3H2 (580 mbar, 4.4 Ci, 164 GBq) trapped on a uranium bed (as uranium tritide) was released by heating (500 °C) and directed into the reaction vial using a tritium manifold. After 3 h of vigorous stirring, the mixture was cooled by liquid nitrogen, and the tritium gas was back-trapped on the waste and tritium U bed. The reaction mixture was filtered through a 0.45 μm PTFE syringe filter, and the tritiation flask and filter were washed by four portions of EtOH (1 mL). Labile activity was removed by the lyophilization of CH3OH/H2O (50:50) (3 × 4 mL) added to the reaction mixture. Analytical HPLC showed a full conversion of the starting material, and preparative HPLC gave 13 mCi of pure [3H]-(Sp,Sp)-4a. The specific activity of [3H]-(Sp,Sp)-4a was determined by ESI-HRMS (profile mode) at 49.1 Ci/mmol. HRMS (ESI): m/z calculated for C32H41T2F2N10O14P2 895.25687, found 895.25907.

    (Rp,Sp)-Bis(POM) Prodrug of 3′,3′-c-Di[8-[3H],2′F,2′dAMP] ([3H]-(Rp,Sp)-4a)

    The synthetic precursor (Rp,Sp)-11 (1 mg, 0.9 μmol), PdO (1.7 mg), PBS (500 μL, pH 7.6), and EtOH (500 μL) were placed in a round-bottomed flask (2 mL). The flask was mounted on a tritium manifold that was placed in a glovebox, and the reaction mixture was degassed by three successive freeze–thaw cycles (liquid nitrogen and a turbopump vacuum). Carrier-free 3H2 (580 mbar, 4.4 Ci, 164 GBq) trapped on a uranium bed (as uranium tritide) was released by heating (500 °C) and directed into the reaction vial using a tritium manifold. After 16 h of vigorous stirring, the mixture was cooled by liquid nitrogen, and the tritium gas was back-trapped on the waste and tritium U bed. The reaction mixture was filtered through a 0.45 μm PTFE syringe filter, and the tritiation flask and filter were washed by four portions of EtOH (1 mL). Labile activity was removed by the lyophilization of CH3OH/H2O (50:50) (3 × 4 mL) added to the reaction mixture. Analytical HPLC showed a full conversion of the starting material, and preparative HPLC gave 1.2 mCi of pure [3H]-(Rp,Sp)-4a. The specific activity of [3H]-(Rp,Sp)-4a was determined by ESI-HRMS (profile mode) at 48.4 Ci/mmol. HRMS (ESI): m/z calculated for C32H41T2F2N10O14P2: calculated 895.25687, found 895.26931.

    (Rp,Rp)-Bis(POM) Prodrug of 3′,3′-Di-c[8-[3H],2′F,2′dAMP] ([3H]-(Rp,Rp)-4a)

    The synthetic precursor (Rp,Rp)-11 (1 mg, 0.9 μmol), PdO (1.2 mg), PBS (300 μL, pH 7.6), and EtOH (800 μL) were placed in a round-bottomed flask (2 mL). The flask was mounted on a tritium manifold that was placed in a glovebox, and the reaction mixture was degassed by three successive freeze–thaw cycles (liquid nitrogen and an ultralow turbopump vacuum). Carrier-free 3H2 (791 mbar, 8.6 Ci, 318 GBq) trapped on a uranium bed (as uranium tritide) was released by heating (500 °C) and directed into the reaction vial using a tritium manifold. After 3 h of vigorous stirring, the mixture was cooled by liquid nitrogen, and the tritium gas was back-trapped on the waste and tritium U bed. The reaction mixture was filtered through a 0.22 μm PVDF syringe filter, and the tritiation flask and filter were washed by four portions of EtOH (1 mL). Labile activity was removed by the lyophilization of CH3OH/H2O (90:10) (3 × 4 mL) added to the reaction mixture. Analytical HPLC showed a full conversion of the starting material, and preparative HPLC gave 2.1 mCi of pure [3H]-(Rp,Rp)-4a. The specific activity of [3H]-(Rp,Rp)-4a was determined by ESI-HRMS (profile mode) at 45.3 Ci/mmol. The product was formulated in DMSO/EtOH 8:2 at a concentration of 2 mCi/mL and stored in a cryopreservation station (−196 °C). HRMS (ESI): m/z calculated for C32H41T2F2N10O14P2: calculated 895.25687, found 895.28122.

    Protein Expression and Purification

    The DNA-encoding truncated cytosolic cyclic dinucleotide binding domain (residues 140–343) of WT or REF STING (R232H) was inserted into the plasmid pHis2 together with an N-terminal 8xHis-SUMO solubility tag using restriction cloning. The proteins were expressed and purified using our standard protocols.(72) The proteins were expressed in the Escherichia coli BL21 (DE3) NiCo bacterial strain using a Luria–Bertani medium. The cells were grown at 37 °C to an OD600 of 0.5. At that point, an IPTG with a final concentration of 200 μM was added. The cells were then cultivated at 18 °C overnight. Pellets of centrifuged cells were resuspended in a lysis buffer (300 mM NaCl, 50 mM Tris pH 8, 30 mM imidazole, 3 mM β-mercaptoethanol, and 10% glycerol) and lysed using a French press. Lysates were centrifuged for 30 min at 30 000 × g. The acquired supernatant was incubated with a Ni-NTA resin (Machery-Nagel) for 30 min and then washed with the lysis buffer. Proteins were eluted using an elution buffer (300 mM NaCl, 50 mM Tris pH 8, 300 mM imidazole, 3 mM β-mercaptoethanol, and 10% glycerol). Eluates were incubated with Ulp1 protease (0.05 mg/mL, 1 h, 4 °C) to remove the 8xHis-SUMO solubilization tag. The proteins were then purified using size exclusion chromatography (SEC) on a HiLoad 16/600 Superdex 75 pg column (GE Healthcare) in SEC buffer (50 mM NaCl and 50 mM Tris pH 7.4), followed by anion exchange chromatography on a HiTrap Q HP (GE Healthcare) column (Buffer A, 50 mM NaCl and 50 mM Tris pH 7.4; Buffer B, 1 M NaCl and 50 mM Tris pH 7.4). The purity of the acquired proteins was verified using SDS-PAGE. The purified protein was concentrated to 20 mg/mL, aliquoted, flash-frozen in liquid nitrogen, and stored at −80 °C until needed.

    Crystallization Experiment and Data Collection

    Crystallization experiments were performed according to our improved protocol.(65) Co-crystallization trials of either WT or REF STING protein with ligands were performed at 20 °C using the sitting drop method. Crystallization mixtures consisted of a 1:1 solution of the protein (1 mM) with the ligand (0.5 mM), which was supplemented with 10 mM EDTA and a well solution. In the case of (Rp)-12, the WT STING crystallized in a well solution that consisted of 1 M sodium/potassium tartrate, 0.2 M Li2SO4 ,and 0.1 M Tris pH 7.0. For REF STING, the well solution consisted of 0.1 M citric acid pH 5 and 20% PEG 6000. Crystals of WT STING in complex with (Rp,Rp)-8 were grown in a well solution that consisted of 0.2 M tripotassium citrate monohydrate, 20% (w/v) PEG 3350, 0.1 M sodium citrate, and 50 mM EDTA. Acquired crystals were flash-frozen in liquid nitrogen using a well solution supplemented with 20% glycerol as a cryoprotectant. Data sets were collected at the home source (Tables S4 and S5).

    Structure Determination and Refinement

    The data sets were processed using XDSapp software.(73) The initial models were obtained by a molecular replacement search model (PDB 4KSY) and further refined using Phenix(74) and Coot(75) software, as summarized in Tables S4 and S5. The visualization and alignment of the final structures were carried out using PYMOL software (Schrödinger, Inc.).

    Differential Scanning Fluorimetry (DSF) with the WT STING Allelic Form

    The DSF reactions were performed in 20 μL reactions in a 96-well format (LightCycler 480 Multiwell Plate 96 white, Roche) in triplicate as described previously.(32) Briefly, the reactions containing 0.1 mg/mL WT STING protein were diluted in 100 mM Tris-HCl buffer pH 7.4 (VWR), 150 mM NaCl (Lach-Ner), 1:500 (v/v) SYPRO Orange Protein Gel Stain (Sigma-Aldrich), and either 150 μM CDN or water were analyzed in a LightCycler 480 II (Roche) system. The first derivative of the fluorescence intensity associated with thermal denaturation of the protein was evaluated and then calculated as the melting temperature (Tm) and the thermal shift (ΔTm), which is the difference of Tm of an apoprotein and a protein in complex with CDN.

    Determination of Compound EC50 Values Using Reporter Cell Lines

    Digitonin Assay
    The digitonin assay was performed as previously described(32) using five different HEK 293T STING ISRE cell lines that expressed the allelic forms of STING, namely WT STING, HAQ STING, AQ STING, Q STING, and REF STING, and the reporter gene luciferase under an IRF3-activated interferon-stimulated response element (ISRE) promoter. Briefly, cells were grown overnight at a density of 250 000 cells/cm2 in poly-d-lysine (Sigma-Aldrich)-coated half area 96-well plates (Greiner Bio-One) that were treated with compounds diluted in a digitonin buffer (50 mM HEPES (pH 7.0), 100 mM KCl, 3 mM MgCl2, 0.1 mM DTT, 85 mM sucrose, 0.2% (w/w) BSA, 1 mM ATP, 0.1 mM GTP, and 10 μg/mL digitonin A) for 30 min at 37 °C in a 5% CO2 atmosphere. Afterward, cells were washed twice with a high-glucose DMEM medium (containing stable l-glutamine; Biowest) supplemented with 10% (v/v) heat-inactivated fetal bovine serum (FBS, Capricorn Scientific) and 1% (v/v) penicillin-streptomycin (P/S, Biowest) and incubated for an additional 6.5 h without compounds. Finally, the luciferase expression was detected with the Brigh-Glo Luciferase Assay System reagent (Promega) according to the manufacturer’s recommendations, and the luminescence was measured using a Spark (TECAN) spectrophotometer. EC50 values were calculated using GraphPad Prism (La Jolla) software as described previously.(32)
    Standard Assay
    HEK 293T WT STING ISRE cells were seeded into poly-d-lysine-coated half area 96-well plates at a density of 250 000 cells/cm2 in a high-glucose DMEM medium (containing stable l-glutamine) supplemented with 10% (v/v) heat-inactivated fetal bovine serum and 1% (v/v) penicillin-streptomycin. After incubation at 37 °C in a 5% CO2 atmosphere overnight, serially diluted compounds were added to the cells for 7 h. In parallel, 293T cells were incubated with the tested compounds for only 30 min (pulse incubation) and washed twice with the fresh medium to remove the compounds, then cultured for an additional 6.5 h without compounds. Finally, the luciferase expression was detected, and the compound-associated EC50 values were determined as described above.
    THP1-Dual Assay
    THP1-Dual cells (Invivogen) were seeded at 106 cells/mL into 96-well plates (VWR) in 100 μL of a THP1-Dual medium containing the RPMI 1640 medium (containing stable l-glutamine) supplemented with 10 mM HEPES (Biowest), 10% (v/v) FBS, 1% (v/v) P/S, 100 μg/mL Normocin (Invivogen), and 10 ng/mL phorbol 12-myristate 13-acetate (PMA; Thermo Fisher Scientific). After 16 h of incubation at 37 °C in a 5% CO2 atmosphere, the medium was exchanged for a THP1-Dual medium without PMA, and the cells were incubated for an additional 24 h. Serially diluted compounds were added to cell cultures and incubated for either 30 min or 7 h at 37 °C in a 5% CO2 atmosphere. The cells were then washed twice with the cell culture medium to remove the compounds and then cultured for an additional 23.5 or 17 h, respectively. Finally, the medium was collected for a Lucia luciferase expression measurement using QUANTI-Luc (Invivogen) according to the manufacturer’s recommendations using a Spark (TECAN) spectrophotometer. Compound-associated EC50 values were determined as described above.

    Cytokine Level Determination

    Buffy coats from healthy individuals were obtained from the Institute of Hematology and Blood Transfusion (IHBT, Prague, Czech Republic). Informed written consent was obtained from each individual enrolled. The study was approved by the institutional review board of IHBT with evidence number 13/06/2012.
    PBMC were isolated from the fresh buffy coats of healthy individuals by SepMate-50 (Stem Cell Technologies) using the Ficoll Paque Plus (GE Healthcare) density gradient centrifugation according to the manufacturer’s protocol. PBMC were then seeded in a concentration of 5 × 106 cells/mL into a 96-well plate (U-shaped bottom; VWR) in 100 μL of the RPMI 1640 medium containing stable l-glutamine supplemented with 10% (v/v) FBS and 1% (v/v) P/S. The cells were cultured with serially diluted compounds for 16 h at 37 °C in a 5% CO2 atmosphere.
    The cells were centrifuged for 5 min at 500 × g and rt. The culture medium was then collected for cytokine profiling of IFNα, IFNγ, and TNFα. The concentration of the cytokines was determined with ProcartaPlex assays (Invitrogen; ThermoFisher Scientific) using the MAGPIX system (Merck) according to the manufacturer’s instruction. Compound-associated EC50 values were determined as described above.

    Uptake and Metabolism of Radiolabeled Compounds

    Uptake Assay
    THP1-Dual cells were seeded at a concentration of 30 × 106 cells/mL in 500 μL of the THP1-Dual medium without PMA, and the metabolism study was initiated by adding 500 μL of the medium containing 2.5 μM [3H]-(Rp,Sp)-4a (20 μCi/mL), 2.5 μM [3H]-(Rp,Rp)-4a (40 μCi/mL), or 250 μM [3H]-1 (340 μCi/mL). The same mixture was used to generate a standard curve of a compound concentration calculation versus the counts per minute (CPM). The cells were collected at time points of 5 min, 20 min, 1 h, 2 h, 4 h, and 6 h by centrifugation for 1 min at 1000 × g. The media was removed completely, and the cells were washed twice with 800 μL of ice-cold PBS before being lysed with 400 μL ice-cold 70% methanol. Lysates were incubated overnight at −20 °C and then centrifuged for 20 min at 13 000 × g to remove cellular debris. The cell lysate (100 μL) was transferred into polyethylene scintillation tubes (Carl Roth) containing 2 mL of the scintillation solution (ROTISZINT eco plus; Carl Roth), and the mixture was mixed well. 3H counts per minute (3H-CPM) were measured using a Tri-Carb 2900TR instrument (PerkinElmer). The standard curve was measured in the same manner. The intracellular concentration of the compounds was calculated using the standard curve and the knowledge of the average volume of one THP1-Dual cell (755.5 μm3).(76)
    Lysates (200 μL) were evaporated, resuspended with 150 μL of MiliQ H2O, and analyzed by HPLC–liquid scintillation using a Waters We2695 system with a W2998 PDA detector (Waters, along with a Ramona Raytest (Elysia s.a.) instrument to detect scintillation. Mobile phases consisted of (A) MiliQ H2O and (B) 50% ACN (Fisher), both of which were supplemented with 100 mM TEAB. Chromatography was run on a Supelcosil LC-18T instrument with dimensions and a particle size of 15 cm × 4.6 mm and 3 μm (Supelco; Merck), respectively, at a flow rate of 1 mL/min and pumped to the Ramona with a scintillation cocktail (Zinsser Analytic) at a flow rate of 2 mL/min. The gradient was as follows: A (100%) 5 min, A (50%) 30 min, A (25%) 50 min, and A (0%) 60 min, with an 80 min total run time. Samples were analyzed using Empowered 3 software (Waters). Retention times for compounds 1, [3H]-(Sp)-3a, [3H]-(Rp)-3a, [3H]-(Sp,Rp)-4a, and [3H]-(Rp,Rp)-4a were 19.8, 37.3, 42.4, 61.6, and 66.6 min, respectively.
    Efflux Assay
    THP1-Dual cells were treated with 1.25 μM [3H]-(Rp,Rp)-4a (40 μCi/mL) for 2 h, washed twice with a THP1-Dual medium to remove the compounds, and seeded into a 24-well plate at a concentration of 15 × 106 cells/mL. Samples were collected and processed as described above at time points of 0 min, 30 min, 1 h, 2 h, 4 h, and 24 h. The measurement was performed as described above, and the loss of the intracellular compound was calculated as the intracellular concentration as described above. The half time of the efflux was calculated using one-phase decay analysis in GraphPad Prism (La Jolla).

    Plasma Stability

    Prodrugs and parent CDNs at a 10 μM concentration were incubated in either mouse or human plasma at 37 °C for 2, 4, 8, 16, 32, 64, and 128 min. Collected aliquots (40 μL) were added to 120 μL of ice-cold 100% acetonitrile containing 1 μM midazolam. After remaining at −80 °C for 30 min to aid plasma protein precipitation, samples were spun at 13 000 × g for 20 min at 4 °C, and the supernatants were evaporated. Compounds were resuspended in 60 μL of 10 mM ammonium acetate, and 2 μL of the solution was applied to an Acquity UPLC BEH C18 column (1.7 μm 2.1 × 50 mm column). A linear gradient from 10 mM ammonium acetate to 100% acetonitrile (column temperature of 40 °C and flow rate of 0.5 mL/min) was used to elute the metabolites. Detection was performed on a PDA (260 nm channel) system and a MS ESI Plus scan using a Waters ACQUITY UPLC H-Class PLUS system with MS SQ Detector 2.

    Statistical Analysis

    The relative maximum activation signals of the prodrugs and CDNs relative to the maximum activation signal of 2′3′-cGAMP or the maximum cytokine production (in pg/mL) were analyzed using the GraphPad Prism software. First, the Sapiro–Wilk normality test was used to determine whether the values had a normal distribution. As the distribution was not normal for all samples, the Kruskal–Wallis nonparametric test was used to determine any significant differences between samples. P-values smaller than 0.05 were considered significant.

    Computational Details

    QM/MM Calculations

    QM/MM calculations were carried out in the same way as in our previous study,(32) and details of our QM/MM coupling scheme are available in the Supporting Information. In brief, the quantum system consisted of approximately 600 atoms (∼70 atoms of the ligands, 18 water molecules, and 486 atoms of the STING protein, which included all interacting residues in the vicinity of the ligand) in their equilibrium QM/MM geometries studied herein. The exact composition of the QM system can be seen in the Supporting Informationf or all eight QM systems. Throughout, the standard hydrogen-link atom approach was used. The QM system was described at the BP86-D3/DZVP-DFT level, while the MM system was described by Amber ff03. The QM/MM calculations were done by employing ComQum software,(77,78) which couples the QM code Turbomole(79) with the Amber MM code.(80)

    Free Energies

    Interaction energies were calculated as the difference between the free energy of a protein–ligand complex and the free energies of the standalone ligand and protein in their relaxed geometries (i.e., global minima)where G′YX denotes the free energy value of the system X in the geometry Y, e.g., G′ligandligand is the free energy of the ligand in its global minimum in a solvent.
    Since the G′proteinprotein is a constant for all systems studied, this value is not needed for the relative G′int values presented in Table 3; thus, no attempts to fill the empty cavity with water molecules and find the global minimum for the protein were made.
    In Table 3, we also use the value G′int,no_strain, which is defined asThis is the interaction energy when neither the protein nor ligand relaxation to their respective equilibrium geometries is considered. The G′int,no_strain value does not have an experimental counterpart but provides insight into the origin of the binding differences of various ligands.
    Strain free energies of the ligand were calculated as the difference between the free energy of a bound-like conformation and its global minimum in a solvent.Free energies were calculated using the DFT/COSMO-RS protocol. We employed the Becke–Perdew 86 (BP86)(81,82) exchange-correlation functional with the def2-TZVPD basis set(83,84) and the D3 empirical dispersion correction with Becke–Johnson damping.(85) The COSMO implicit solvation model with FINE cavities ($cosmo_isorad keyword) and the ideal conductor (ε = ∞) settings were used. All DFT calculations were done in Turbomole ver. 7.4.(79) The COSMO-RS(86,87) methodology was used as implemented in COSMOtherm 2019(88) using the “BP_TZVPD_FINE_19.ctd” parametrization file.
    Free energies of a given compound (entity) were then computed aswhere ECOSMO corresponds to the BP86-D3BJ/COSMO (ε = ∞) energy of the molecule, ΔE is the averaged correction for the dielectric energy,(86) and μ is the chemical potential of the conformer. Global minima for the calculation of strain energies were obtained as structures with the lowest free energies from the set of conformers, which were obtained using a PRIME(89) algorithm (by employing thorough settings) as implemented in the Schrodinger re. 2019-1 suite(90) and optimized using the DFT/COSMO protocol described above.

    Calculations of NMR Parameters

    Selected ligands were also subjected to an additional geometry optimization at the DFT level using the B3LYP functional(82,91) (no dispersion correction) with the standard 6-31+G(2d,p) basis set, and the polarizable continuum was model used for implicit water solvation.(92,93) The vibrational frequencies and free energies were calculated for all the optimized structures, and the stationary point (minimum) character was thus confirmed. The Gaussian16 program package(94) was used in these calculations.

    This article references 94 other publications.

    1. 1
      Motwani, M.; Pesiridis, S.; Fitzgerald, K. A. DNA Sensing by the CGAS-STING Pathway in Health and Disease. Nat. Rev. Genet. 2019, 20 (11), 657– 674,  DOI: 10.1038/s41576-019-0151-1
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      1
      DNA sensing by the cGAS-STING pathway in health and disease
      Motwani, Mona; Pesiridis, Scott; Fitzgerald, Katherine A.
      Nature Reviews Genetics (2019), 20 (11), 657-674CODEN: NRGAAM; ISSN:1471-0056. (Nature Research)
      A review. The detection of pathogens through nucleic acid sensors is a defining principle of innate immunity. RNA-sensing and DNA-sensing receptors sample subcellular compartments for foreign nucleic acids and, upon recognition, trigger immune signalling pathways for host defense. Over the past decade, our understanding of how the recognition of nucleic acids is coupled to immune gene expression has advanced considerably, particularly for the DNA-sensing receptor cyclic GMP-AMP synthase (cGAS) and its downstream signalling effector stimulator of interferon genes (STING), as well as the mol. components and regulation of this pathway. Moreover, the ability of self-DNA to engage cGAS has emerged as an important mechanism fuelling the development of inflammation and implicating the cGAS-STING pathway in human inflammatory diseases and cancer. This detailed mechanistic and biol. understanding is paving the way for the development and clin. application of pharmacol. agonists and antagonists in the treatment of chronic inflammation and cancer.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1MXhsVGqtbvM&md5=f13ade7f14b63b453192b5d05f7c9f0b
    2. 2
      Paludan, S. R.; Bowie, A. G. Immune Sensing of DNA. Immunity 2013, 38 (5), 870– 880,  DOI: 10.1016/j.immuni.2013.05.004
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      2
      Immune Sensing of DNA
      Paludan, Soeren R.; Bowie, Andrew G.
      Immunity (2013), 38 (5), 870-880CODEN: IUNIEH; ISSN:1074-7613. (Elsevier Inc.)
      A review. Although it has been appreciated for some years that cytosolic DNA is immune stimulatory, it is only in the past five years that the mol. basis of DNA sensing by the innate immune system has begun to be revealed. In particular it has been described how DNA induces type I interferon, central in antiviral responses and a mediator of autoimmunity. To date more than ten cytosolic receptors of DNA have been proposed, but STING is a key adaptor protein for most DNA-sensing pathways, and we are now beginning to understand the signaling mechanisms for STING. In this review we describe the recent progress in understanding signaling mechanisms activated by DNA and the relevance of DNA sensing to pathogen responses and autoimmunity. We highlight new insights gained into how and why the immune system responds to both pathogen and self DNA and define important questions that now need to be addressed in the field of innate immune activation by DNA.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXotF2ntbo%253D&md5=6930585ac2dfebfc063ce138650126eb
    3. 3
      Ablasser, A.; Goldeck, M.; Cavlar, T.; Deimling, T.; Witte, G.; Röhl, I.; Hopfner, K.-P.; Ludwig, J.; Hornung, V. CGAS Produces a 2’-5′-Linked Cyclic Dinucleotide Second Messenger That Activates STING. Nature 2013, 498 (7454), 380– 384,  DOI: 10.1038/nature12306
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      3
      cGAS produces a 2'-5'-linked cyclic dinucleotide second messenger that activates STING
      Ablasser, Andrea; Goldeck, Marion; Cavlar, Taner; Deimling, Tobias; Witte, Gregor; Roehl, Ingo; Hopfner, Karl-Peter; Ludwig, Janos; Hornung, Veit
      Nature (London, United Kingdom) (2013), 498 (7454), 380-384CODEN: NATUAS; ISSN:0028-0836. (Nature Publishing Group)
      Detection of cytoplasmic DNA represents one of the most fundamental mechanisms of the innate immune system to sense the presence of microbial pathogens. Moreover, erroneous detection of endogenous DNA by the same sensing mechanisms has an important pathophysiol. role in certain sterile inflammatory conditions. The endoplasmic reticulum-resident protein STING is critically required for the initiation of type I interferon signalling upon detection of cytosolic DNA of both exogenous and endogenous origin. Next to its pivotal role in DNA sensing, STING also serves as a direct receptor for the detection of cyclic dinucleotides, which function as second messenger mols. in bacteria. DNA recognition, however, is triggered in an indirect fashion that depends on a recently characterized cytoplasmic nucleotidyl transferase, termed cGAMP synthase (cGAS), which upon interaction with DNA synthesizes a dinucleotide mol. that in turn binds to and activates STING. We here show in vivo and in vitro that the cGAS-catalyzed reaction product is distinct from previously characterized cyclic dinucleotides. Using a combinatorial approach based on mass spectrometry, enzymic digestion, NMR anal. and chem. synthesis, we demonstrate that cGAS produces a cyclic GMP-AMP dinucleotide, which comprises a 2'-5' and a 3'-5' phosphodiester linkage >Gp(2'-5')Ap(3'-5')>. We found that the presence of this 2'-5' linkage was required to exert potent activation of human STING. Moreover, we show that cGAS first catalyzes the synthesis of a linear 2'-5'-linked dinucleotide, which is then subject to cGAS-dependent cyclization in a second step through a 3'-5' phosphodiester linkage. This 13-membered ring structure defines a novel class of second messenger mols., extending the family of 2'-5'-linked antiviral biomols.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXpslGhsrk%253D&md5=78743675ef6c36bb32d7eb80a2030c46
    4. 4
      Gao, P.; Ascano, M.; Wu, Y.; Barchet, W.; Gaffney, B. L.; Zillinger, T.; Serganov, A. A.; Liu, Y.; Jones, R. A.; Hartmann, G.; Tuschl, T.; Patel, D. J. Cyclic [G(2’,5′)PA(3′,5′)p] Is the Metazoan Second Messenger Produced by DNA-Activated Cyclic GMP-AMP Synthase. Cell 2013, 153 (5), 1094– 1107,  DOI: 10.1016/j.cell.2013.04.046
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      4
      Cyclic [G(2',5')pA(3',5')p] is the metazoan second messenger produced by DNA-activated cyclic GMP-AMP synthase
      Gao, Pu; Ascano, Manuel; Wu, Yang; Barchet, Winfried; Gaffney, Barbara L.; Zillinger, Thomas; Serganov, Artem A.; Liu, Yizhou; Jones, Roger A.; Hartmann, Gunther; Tuschl, Thomas; Patel, Dinshaw J.
      Cell (Cambridge, MA, United States) (2013), 153 (5), 1094-1107CODEN: CELLB5; ISSN:0092-8674. (Cell Press)
      Recent studies identified cGMP-AMP (cGAMP) as a metazoan second messenger triggering an interferon response. cGAMP is generated from GTP and ATP by cytoplasmic dsDNA sensor cGAMP synthase (cGAS). We combined structural, chem., biochem., and cellular assays to demonstrate that this second messenger contains G(2',5')pA and A(3',5')pG phosphodiester linkages, designated c[G(2',5')pA(3',5')p]. We show that, upon dsDNA binding, cGAS is activated through conformational transitions, resulting in formation of a catalytically competent and accessible nucleotide-binding pocket for generation of c[G(2',5')pA(3',5')p]. We demonstrate that cyclization occurs in a stepwise manner through initial generation of 5'-pppG(2',5')pA prior to cyclization to c[G(2',5')pA(3',5')p], with the latter positioned precisely in the catalytic pocket. Mutants of cGAS dsDNA-binding or catalytic pocket residues exhibit reduced or abrogated activity. Our studies have identified c[G(2',5')pA(3',5')p] as a founding member of a family of metazoan 2',5'-contg. cyclic heterodinucleotide second messengers distinct from bacterial 3',5' cyclic dinucleotides.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXnt1aht7Y%253D&md5=32efa5389dcb1023ddcc244641341083
    5. 5
      Sun, L.; Wu, J.; Du, F.; Chen, X.; Chen, Z. J. Cyclic GMP-AMP Synthase Is a Cytosolic DNA Sensor That Activates the Type I Interferon Pathway. Science 2013, 339 (6121), 786– 791,  DOI: 10.1126/science.1232458
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      5
      Cyclic GMP-AMP Synthase Is a Cytosolic DNA Sensor That Activates the Type I Interferon Pathway
      Sun, Lijun; Wu, Jiaxi; Du, Fenghe; Chen, Xiang; Chen, Zhijian J.
      Science (Washington, DC, United States) (2013), 339 (6121), 786-791CODEN: SCIEAS; ISSN:0036-8075. (American Association for the Advancement of Science)
      The presence of DNA in the cytoplasm of mammalian cells is a danger signal that triggers host immune responses such as the prodn. of type I interferons. Cytosolic DNA induces interferons through the prodn. of cyclic guanosine monophosphate-adenosine monophosphate (cyclic GMP-AMP, or cGAMP), which binds to and activates the adaptor protein STING. Through biochem. fractionation and quant. mass spectrometry, we identified a cGAMP synthase (cGAS), which belongs to the nucleotidyltransferase family. Overexpression of cGAS activated the transcription factor IRF3 and induced interferon-β in a STING-dependent manner. Knockdown of cGAS inhibited IRF3 activation and interferon-β induction by DNA transfection or DNA virus infection. CGAS bound to DNA in the cytoplasm and catalyzed cGAMP synthesis. These results indicate that cGAS is a cytosolic DNA sensor that induces interferons by producing the second messenger cGAMP.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXit1ygurw%253D&md5=fe9a64a9c0441eb00852900be8d683bf
    6. 6
      Ishikawa, H.; Barber, G. N. STING Is an Endoplasmic Reticulum Adaptor That Facilitates Innate Immune Signalling. Nature 2008, 455 (7213), 674– 678,  DOI: 10.1038/nature07317
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      6
      STING is an endoplasmic reticulum adaptor that facilitates innate immune signalling
      Ishikawa, Hiroki; Barber, Glen N.
      Nature (London, United Kingdom) (2008), 455 (7213), 674-678CODEN: NATUAS; ISSN:0028-0836. (Nature Publishing Group)
      The cellular innate immune system is essential for recognizing pathogen infection and for establishing effective host defense. But crit. mol. determinants responsible for facilitating an appropriate immune response-following infection with DNA and RNA viruses, for example-remain to be identified. Here the authors report the identification, following expression cloning, of a mol. (STING; stimulator of interferon genes) that appears essential for effective innate immune signaling processes. It comprises five putative transmembrane regions, predominantly resides in the endoplasmic reticulum and is able to activate both NF-κB and IRF3 transcription pathways to induce expression of type I interferon (IFN-α and IFN-β) and exert a potent anti-viral state following expression. In contrast, loss of STING rendered murine embryonic fibroblasts extremely susceptible to neg.-stranded virus infection, including vesicular stomatitis virus. Further, STING ablation abrogated the ability of intracellular B-form DNA, as well as members of the herpesvirus family, to induce IFN-β, but did not significantly affect the Toll-like receptor (TLR) pathway. Yeast two-hybrid and co-immunopptn. studies indicated that STING interacts with RIG-I and with SSR2 (also known as TRAPβ), which is a member of the translocon-assocd. protein (TRAP) complex required for protein translocation across the endoplasmic reticulum membrane following translation. Ablation by RNA interference of both TRAPβ and translocon adaptor SEC61β was subsequently found to inhibit STING's ability to stimulate expression of IFN-β. Thus, as well as identifying a regulator of innate immune signaling, these results imply a potential role for the translocon in innate signaling pathways activated by select viruses as well as intracellular DNA.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXhtF2hsbzL&md5=67bd86a114023c8d6c68489ab7e33009
    7. 7
      Zhong, B.; Yang, Y.; Li, S.; Wang, Y. Y.; Li, Y.; Diao, F.; Lei, C.; He, X.; Zhang, L.; Tien, P.; Shu, H.-B. The Adaptor Protein MITA Links Virus-Sensing Receptors to IRF3 Transcription Factor Activation. Immunity 2008, 29 (4), 538– 550,  DOI: 10.1016/j.immuni.2008.09.003
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      7
      The adaptor protein MITA links virus-sensing receptors to IRF3 transcription factor activation
      Zhong, Bo; Yang, Yan; Li, Shu; Wang, Yan-Yi; Li, Ying; Diao, Feici; Lei, Caoqi; He, Xiao; Zhang, Lu; Tien, Po; Shu, Hong-Bing
      Immunity (2008), 29 (4), 538-550CODEN: IUNIEH; ISSN:1074-7613. (Cell Press)
      Viral infection triggers activation of transcription factors such as NF-κB and IRF3, which collaborate to induce type I interferons (IFNs) and elicit innate antiviral response. Here, the authors identified MITA as a crit. mediator of virus-triggered type I IFN signaling by expression cloning. Overexpression of MITA activated IRF3, whereas knockdown of MITA inhibited virus-triggered activation of IRF3, expression of type I IFNs, and cellular antiviral response. MITA was found to localize to the outer membrane of mitochondria and to be assocd. with VISA, a mitochondrial protein that acts as an adaptor in virus-triggered signaling. MITA also interacted with IRF3 and recruited the kinase TBK1 to the VISA-assocd. complex. MITA was phosphorylated by TBK1, which is required for MITA-mediated activation of IRF3. The authors' results suggest that MITA is a crit. mediator of virus-triggered IRF3 activation and IFN expression and further demonstrate the importance of certain mitochondrial proteins in innate antiviral immunity.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXhtlWntb7P&md5=b4197f541f33cc09897cd5516d05eab3
    8. 8
      Sun, W.; Li, Y.; Chen, L.; Chen, H.; You, F.; Zhou, X.; Zhou, Y.; Zhai, Z.; Chen, D.; Jiang, Z. ERIS, an Endoplasmic Reticulum IFN Stimulator, Activates Innate Immune Signaling through Dimerization. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2009, 106 (21), 8653– 8658,  DOI: 10.1073/pnas.0900850106
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      8
      ERIS, an endoplasmic reticulum IFN stimulator, activates innate immune signaling through dimerization
      Sun, Wenxiang; Li, Yang; Chen, Lu; Chen, Huihui; You, Fuping; Zhou, Xiang; Zhou, Yi; Zhai, Zhonghe; Chen, Danying; Jiang, Zhengfan
      Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America (2009), 106 (21), 8653-8658CODEN: PNASA6; ISSN:0027-8424. (National Academy of Sciences)
      The authors report here the identification and characterization of a protein, ERIS, an endoplasmic reticulum (ER) IFN stimulator, which is a strong type I IFN stimulator and plays a pivotal role in response to both non-self-cytosolic RNA and dsDNA. ERIS (also known as STING or MITA) resided exclusively on ER membrane. The ER retention/retrieval sequence RIR was crit. to retain the protein on ER membrane and to maintain its integrity. ERIS was dimerized on innate immune challenges. Coumermycin-induced ERIS dimerization led to strong and fast IFN induction, suggesting that dimerization of ERIS was crit. for self-activation and subsequent downstream signaling.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXnt1SqsL0%253D&md5=62c71f1043475e9647e303dfd942b45c
    9. 9
      Zhang, X.; Shi, H.; Wu, J.; Zhang, X.; Sun, L.; Chen, C.; Chen, Z. J. Cyclic GMP-AMP Containing Mixed Phosphodiester Linkages Is an Endogenous High-Affinity Ligand for STING. Mol. Cell 2013, 51 (2), 226– 235,  DOI: 10.1016/j.molcel.2013.05.022
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      9
      Cyclic GMP-AMP Containing Mixed Phosphodiester Linkages Is An Endogenous High-Affinity Ligand for STING
      Zhang, Xu; Shi, Heping; Wu, Jiaxi; Zhang, Xuewu; Sun, Lijun; Chen, Chuo; Chen, Zhijian J.
      Molecular Cell (2013), 51 (2), 226-235CODEN: MOCEFL; ISSN:1097-2765. (Elsevier Inc.)
      The presence of microbial or self DNA in the cytoplasm of mammalian cells is a danger signal detected by the DNA sensor cyclic-GMP-AMP (cGAMP) synthase (cGAS), which catalyzes the prodn. of cGAMP that in turn serves as a second messenger to activate innate immune responses. Here we show that endogenous cGAMP in mammalian cells contains two distinct phosphodiester linkages, one between 2'-OH of GMP and 5'-phosphate of AMP, and the other between 3'-OH of AMP and 5'-phosphate of GMP. This mol., termed 2'3'-cGAMP, is unique in that it binds to the adaptor protein STING with a much greater affinity than cGAMP mols. contg. other combinations of phosphodiester linkages. The crystal structure of STING bound to 2'3'-cGAMP revealed the structural basis of this high-affinity binding and a ligand-induced conformational change in STING that may underlie its activation.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXptFOgsb0%253D&md5=871a86c787ef5bd7793bae9cfc091e33
    10. 10
      Mukai, K.; Konno, H.; Akiba, T.; Uemura, T.; Waguri, S.; Kobayashi, T.; Barber, G. N.; Arai, H.; Taguchi, T. Activation of STING Requires Palmitoylation at the Golgi. Nat. Commun. 2016, 7 (May), 11932,  DOI: 10.1038/ncomms11932
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      10
      Activation of STING requires palmitoylation at the Golgi
      Mukai, Kojiro; Konno, Hiroyasu; Akiba, Tatsuya; Uemura, Takefumi; Waguri, Satoshi; Kobayashi, Toshihide; Barber, Glen N.; Arai, Hiroyuki; Taguchi, Tomohiko
      Nature Communications (2016), 7 (), 11932CODEN: NCAOBW; ISSN:2041-1723. (Nature Publishing Group)
      Stimulator of interferon genes (STING) is essential for the type I interferon response against DNA pathogens. In response to the presence of DNA and/or cyclic dinucleotides, STING translocates from the endoplasmic reticulum to perinuclear compartments. However, the role of this subcellular translocation remains poorly defined. Here we show that palmitoylation of STING at the Golgi is essential for activation of STING. Treatment with palmitoylation inhibitor 2-bromopalmitate (2-BP) suppresses palmitoylation of STING and abolishes the type I interferon response. Mutation of two membrane-proximal Cys residues (Cys88/91) suppresses palmitoylation, and this STING mutant cannot induce STING-dependent host defense genes. STING variants that constitutively induce the type I interferon response were found in patients with autoimmune diseases. The response elicited by these STING variants is effectively inhibited by 2-BP or an introduction of Cys88/91Ser mutation. Our results may lead to new treatments for cytosolic DNA-triggered autoinflammatory diseases.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XhtVKit7rF&md5=75f2fddd8595e75b8f6f6891a9644440
    11. 11
      Dobbs, N.; Burnaevskiy, N.; Chen, D.; Gonugunta, V. K.; Alto, N. M.; Yan, N. STING Activation by Translocation from the ER Is Associated with Infection and Autoinflammatory Disease. Cell Host Microbe 2015, 18 (2), 157– 168,  DOI: 10.1016/j.chom.2015.07.001
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      11
      STING Activation by Translocation from the ER Is Associated with Infection and Autoinflammatory Disease
      Dobbs, Nicole; Burnaevskiy, Nikolay; Chen, Didi; Gonugunta, Vijay K.; Alto, Neal M.; Yan, Nan
      Cell Host & Microbe (2015), 18 (2), 157-168CODEN: CHMECB; ISSN:1931-3128. (Elsevier Inc.)
      STING is an ER-assocd. membrane protein that is crit. for innate immune sensing of pathogens. STING-mediated activation of the IFN-I pathway through the TBK1/IRF3 signaling axis involves both cyclic-dinucleotide binding and its translocation from the ER to vesicles. However, how these events are coordinated, and the exact mechanism of STING activation, remain poorly understood. Here, we found that the Shigella effector protein IpaJ potently inhibits STING signaling by blocking its translocation from the ER to ERGIC, even in the context of dinucleotide binding. Reconstitution using purified components revealed STING translocation as the rate-limiting event in maximal signal transduction. Furthermore, STING mutations assocd. with autoimmunity in humans were found to cause constitutive ER exit and to activate STING independent of cGAMP binding. Together, these data provide compelling evidence for an ER retention and ERGIC/Golgi-trafficking mechanism of STING regulation that is subverted by bacterial pathogens and is deregulated in human genetic disease.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXht1KmtbfN&md5=f2eb33aa6f198888f7b1c0c7544d4728
    12. 12
      Shang, G.; Zhang, C.; Chen, Z. J.; Bai, X.; Zhang, X. Cryo-EM Structures of STING Reveal Its Mechanism of Activation by Cyclic GMP-AMP. Nature 2019, 567 (7748), 389– 393,  DOI: 10.1038/s41586-019-0998-5
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      12
      Cryo-EM structures of STING reveal its mechanism of activation by cyclic GMP-AMP
      Shang, Guijun; Zhang, Conggang; Chen, Zhijian J.; Bai, Xiao-chen; Zhang, Xuewu
      Nature (London, United Kingdom) (2019), 567 (7748), 389-393CODEN: NATUAS; ISSN:0028-0836. (Nature Research)
      Infections by pathogens that contain DNA trigger the prodn. of type-I interferons and inflammatory cytokines through cGMP-AMP synthase, which produces 2'3'-cGMP-AMP (cGAMP) that binds to and activates stimulator of interferon genes (STING; also known as TMEM173, MITA, ERIS and MPYS). STING is an endoplasmic-reticulum membrane protein that contains four transmembrane helixes followed by a cytoplasmic ligand-binding and signaling domain. The cytoplasmic domain of STING forms a dimer, which undergoes a conformational change upon binding to cGAMP. However, it remains unclear how this conformational change leads to STING activation. Here we present cryo-electron microscopy structures of full-length STING from human and chicken in the inactive dimeric state (about 80 kDa in size), as well as cGAMP-bound chicken STING in both the dimeric and tetrameric states. The structures show that the transmembrane and cytoplasmic regions interact to form an integrated, domain-swapped dimeric assembly. Closure of the ligand-binding domain, induced by cGAMP, leads to a 180° rotation of the ligand-binding domain relative to the transmembrane domain. This rotation is coupled to a conformational change in a loop on the side of the ligand-binding-domain dimer, which leads to the formation of the STING tetramer and higher-order oligomers through side-by-side packing. This model of STING oligomerization and activation is supported by our structure-based mutational analyses.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1MXmsV2iur0%253D&md5=ffedac41ff3fbba8d38f9ec143401aab

      [Crossref], [PubMed], Google Scholar

      Tsuchiya, Y.; Jounai, N.; Takeshita, F.; Ishii, K. J.; Mizuguchi, K. Ligand-Induced Ordering of the C-Terminal Tail Primes STING for Phosphorylation by TBK1. EBioMedicine 2016, 9, 87– 96,  DOI: 10.1016/j.ebiom.2016.05.039
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      14
      Ligand-induced Ordering of the C-terminal Tail Primes STING for Phosphorylation by TBK1
      Tsuchiya Yuko; Mizuguchi Kenji; Jounai Nao; Takeshita Fumihiko; Ishii Ken J
      EBioMedicine (2016), 9 (), 87-96 ISSN:.
      The innate immune protein Stimulator of interferon genes (STING) promotes the induction of interferon beta (IFN-β) production via the phosphorylation of its C-terminal tail (CTT) by TANK-binding kinase 1 (TBK1). Potent ligands of STING are, therefore, promising candidates for novel anti-cancer drugs or vaccine adjuvants. However, the intrinsically flexible CTT poses serious problems in in silico drug discovery. Here, we performed molecular dynamics simulations of the STING fragment containing the CTT in ligand-bound and unbound forms and observed that the binding of a potent ligand cyclic GMP-AMP (cGAMP) induced a local structure in the CTT, reminiscent of the known structure of a TBK1 substrate. The subsequent molecular biological experiments confirmed the observed dynamics of the CTT and identified essential residues for the activation of the IFN-β promoter, leading us to propose a new mechanism of STING activation.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BC2s7isF2rsg%253D%253D&md5=40f923011f762f36ddebd44f6b65c6f9

      Abe, T.; Barber, G. N. Cytosolic-DNA-Mediated, STING-Dependent Proinflammatory Gene Induction Necessitates Canonical NF-KB Activation through TBK1. J. Virol. 2014, 88 (10), 5328– 5341,  DOI: 10.1128/JVI.00037-14
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      15
      Cytosolic-DNA-mediated, STING-dependent proinflammatory gene induction necessitates canonical NF-κB activation through TBK1
      Abe, Takayuki; Barber, Glen N.
      Journal of Virology (2014), 88 (10), 5328-5341, 15 pp.CODEN: JOVIAM; ISSN:1098-5514. (American Society for Microbiology)
      STING (stimulator of interferon genes) is known to control the induction of innate immune genes in response to the recognition of cytosolic DNA species, including the genomes of viruses such as herpes simplex virus 1 (HSV-1). However, while STING is essential for protection of the host against numerous DNA pathogens, sustained STING activity can lead to lethal inflammatory disease. It is known that STING utilizes interferon regulatory factor 3 (IRF3) and nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) pathways to exert its effects, although the signal transduction mechanisms remain to be clarified fully. Here we demonstrate that in addn. to the activation of these pathways, potent induction of the Jun N-terminal protein kinase/stress-activated protein kinase (JNK/SAPK) pathway was similarly obsd. in response to STING activation by double-stranded DNA (dsDNA). Furthermore, TANK-binding kinase 1 (TBK1) assocd. with STING was found to facilitate dsDNA-mediated canonical activation of NF-κB as well as IRF3 to promote proinflammatory gene transcription. The triggering of NF-κB function was noted to require TRAF6 activation. Our findings detail a novel dsDNA-mediated NF-κB activation pathway facilitated through a STING-TRAF6-TBK1 axis and suggest a target for therapeutic intervention to plausibly stimulate antiviral activity or, alternatively, avert dsDNA-mediated inflammatory disease.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXhsVGnu7vF&md5=1dcf97765e322870b4e1e6f9b772cbc0

      Schneider, W. M.; Chevillotte, M. D.; Rice, C. M. Interferon-Stimulated Genes: A Complex Web of Host Defenses. Annu. Rev. Immunol. 2014, 32 (3), 513– 545,  DOI: 10.1146/annurev-immunol-032713-120231

      16
      Interferon-stimulated genes: a complex web of host defenses
      Schneider, William M.; Chevillotte, Meike Dittmann; Rice, Charles M.
      Annual Review of Immunology (2014), 32 (), 513-545CODEN: ARIMDU; ISSN:0732-0582. (Annual Reviews)
      A review. Interferon-stimulated gene (ISG) products take on a no. of diverse roles. Collectively, they are highly effective at resisting and controlling pathogens. In this review, we begin by introducing interferon (IFN) and the JAK-STAT signaling pathway to highlight features that impact ISG prodn. Next, we describe ways in which ISGs both enhance innate pathogen-sensing capabilities and neg. regulate signaling through the JAK-STAT pathway. Several ISGs that directly inhibit virus infection are described with an emphasis on those that impact early and late stages of the virus life cycle. Finally, we describe ongoing efforts to identify and characterize antiviral ISGs, and we provide a forward-looking perspective on the ISG landscape.

      Regulation of type I interferon responses
      Ivashkiv, Lionel B.; Donlin, Laura T.
      Nature Reviews Immunology (2014), 14 (1), 36-49CODEN: NRIABX; ISSN:1474-1733. (Nature Publishing Group)
      A review. Type I interferons (IFNs) activate intracellular antimicrobial programs and influence the development of innate and adaptive immune responses. Canonical type I IFN signalling activates the Janus kinase (JAK)-signal transducer and activator of transcription (STAT) pathway, leading to transcription of IFN-stimulated genes (ISGs). Host, pathogen and environmental factors regulate the responses of cells to this signalling pathway and thus calibrate host defences while limiting tissue damage and preventing autoimmunity. Here, we summarize the signalling and epigenetic mechanisms that regulate type I IFN-induced STAT activation and ISG transcription and translation. These regulatory mechanisms det. the biol. outcomes of type I IFN responses and whether pathogens are cleared effectively or chronic infection or autoimmune disease ensues.

      18
      STING: infection, inflammation and cancer
      Barber, Glen N.
      Nature Reviews Immunology (2015), 15 (12), 760-770CODEN: NRIABX; ISSN:1474-1733. (Nature Publishing Group)
      The rapid detection of microbial agents is essential for the effective initiation of host defense mechanisms against infection. Understanding how cells detect cytosolic DNA to trigger innate immune gene transcription has important implications - not only for comprehending the immune response to pathogens but also for elucidating the causes of autoinflammatory disease involving the sensing of self-DNA and the generation of effective antitumor adaptive immunity. The discovery of the STING (stimulator of interferon genes)-controlled innate immune pathway, which mediates cytosolic DNA-induced signalling events, has recently provided important insights into these processes, opening the way for the development of novel immunization regimes, as well as therapies to treat autoinflammatory disease and cancer.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXhvFWitrvK&md5=e5d3221d27ab9d52802fae5726d49c76
    19. 19
      Burdette, D. L.; Monroe, K. M.; Sotelo-Troha, K.; Iwig, J. S.; Eckert, B.; Hyodo, M.; Hayakawa, Y.; Vance, R. E. STING Is a Direct Innate Immune Sensor of Cyclic Di-GMP. Nature 2011, 478 (7370), 515– 518,  DOI: 10.1038/nature10429
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      19
      STING is a direct innate immune sensor of cyclic di-GMP
      Burdette, Dara L.; Monroe, Kathryn M.; Sotelo-Troha, Katia; Iwig, Jeff S.; Eckert, Barbara; Hyodo, Mamoru; Hayakawa, Yoshihiro; Vance, Russell E.
      Nature (London, United Kingdom) (2011), 478 (7370), 515-518CODEN: NATUAS; ISSN:0028-0836. (Nature Publishing Group)
      The innate immune system detects infection by using germline-encoded receptors that are specific for conserved microbial mols. The recognition of microbial ligands leads to the prodn. of cytokines, such as type I interferons (IFNs), that are essential for successful pathogen elimination. Cytosolic detection of pathogen-derived DNA is one major mechanism of inducing IFN prodn., and this process requires signaling through TANK binding kinase 1 (TBK1) and its downstream transcription factor, IFN-regulatory factor 3 (IRF3). In addn., a transmembrane protein called STING (stimulator of IFN genes; also known as MITA, ERIS, MPYS and TMEM173) functions as an essential signaling adaptor, linking the cytosolic detection of DNA to the TBK1-IRF3 signaling axis. Recently, unique nucleic acids called cyclic dinucleotides, which function as conserved signaling mols. in bacteria, have also been shown to induce a STING-dependent type I IFN response. However, a mammalian sensor of cyclic dinucleotides has not been identified. Here the authors report evidence that STING itself is an innate immune sensor of cyclic dinucleotides. The authors demonstrate that STING binds directly to radiolabeled cyclic diguanylate monophosphate (c-di-GMP), and the authors show that unlabeled cyclic dinucleotides, but not other nucleotides or nucleic acids, compete with c-di-GMP for binding to STING. Furthermore, the authors identify mutations in STING that selectively affect the response to cyclic dinucleotides without affecting the response to DNA. Thus, STING seems to function as a direct sensor of cyclic dinucleotides, in addn. to its established role as a signaling adaptor in the IFN response to cytosolic DNA. Cyclic dinucleotides have shown promise as novel vaccine adjuvants and immunotherapeutics, and the authors' results provide insight into the mechanism by which cyclic dinucleotides are sensed by the innate immune system.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXht1WltLbL&md5=179c4ebb96c6e0385de0370ac42c9bbe
    20. 20
      Danilchanka, O.; Mekalanos, J. J. Cyclic Dinucleotides and the Innate Immune Response. Cell 2013, 154 (5), 962– 970,  DOI: 10.1016/j.cell.2013.08.014
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      20
      Cyclic Dinucleotides and the Innate Immune Response
      Danilchanka, Olga; Mekalanos, John J.
      Cell (Cambridge, MA, United States) (2013), 154 (5), 962-970CODEN: CELLB5; ISSN:0092-8674. (Cell Press)
      A review. Cyclic dinucleotides (CDNs) have been previously recognized as important secondary signaling mols. in bacteria and, more recently, in mammalian cells. In the former case, they represent secondary messengers affecting numerous responses of the prokaryotic cell, whereas in the latter, they act as agonists of the innate immune response. Remarkable new discoveries have linked these two patterns of utilization of CDNs as secondary messengers and have revealed unexpected influences they likely had on shaping human genetic variation. This review summarizes these recent insights and provides a perspective on future unanswered questions in this exciting field.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXhtlGru77M&md5=f22ca5969721a78d91b8d49d1e86f14d
    21. 21
      Luteijn, R. D.; Zaver, S. A.; Gowen, B. G.; Wyman, S. K.; Garelis, N. E.; Onia, L.; McWhirter, S. M.; Katibah, G. E.; Corn, J. E.; Woodward, J. J.; Raulet, D. H. SLC19A1 Transports Immunoreactive Cyclic Dinucleotides. Nature 2019, 573 (7774), 434– 438,  DOI: 10.1038/s41586-019-1553-0
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      21
      SLC19A1 transports immunoreactive cyclic dinucleotides
      Luteijn, Rutger D.; Zaver, Shivam A.; Gowen, Benjamin G.; Wyman, Stacia K.; Garelis, Nick E.; Onia, Liberty; McWhirter, Sarah M.; Katibah, George E.; Corn, Jacob E.; Woodward, Joshua J.; Raulet, David H.
      Nature (London, United Kingdom) (2019), 573 (7774), 434-438CODEN: NATUAS; ISSN:0028-0836. (Nature Research)
      The accumulation of DNA in the cytosol serves as a key immunostimulatory signal assocd. with infections, cancer and genomic damage. Cytosolic DNA triggers immune responses by activating the cyclic GMP-AMP synthase (cGAS)-stimulator of interferon genes (STING) pathway. The binding of DNA to cGAS activates its enzymic activity, leading to the synthesis of a second messenger, cyclic guanosine monophosphate-adenosine monophosphate (2'3'-cGAMP). This cyclic dinucleotide (CDN) activates STING, which in turn activates the transcription factors interferon regulatory factor 3 (IRF3) and nuclear factor κ-light-chain-enhancer of activated B cells (NF-κB), promoting the transcription of genes encoding type I interferons and other cytokines and mediators that stimulate a broader immune response. Exogenous 2'3'-cGAMP produced by malignant cells and other CDNs, including those produced by bacteria and synthetic CDNs used in cancer immunotherapy, must traverse the cell membrane to activate STING in target cells. How these charged CDNs pass through the lipid bilayer is unknown. Here we used a genome-wide CRISPR-interference screen to identify the reduced folate carrier SLC19A1, a folate-org. phosphate antiporter, as the major transporter of CDNs. Depleting SLC19A1 in human cells inhibits CDN uptake and functional responses, and overexpressing SLC19A1 increases both uptake and functional responses. In human cell lines and primary cells ex vivo, CDN uptake is inhibited by folates as well as two medications approved for treatment of inflammatory diseases, sulfasalazine and the antifolate methotrexate. The identification of SLC19A1 as the major transporter of CDNs into cells has implications for the immunotherapeutic treatment of cancer, host responsiveness to CDN-producing pathogenic microorganisms and-potentially-for some inflammatory diseases.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1MXhslKhsrzP&md5=df739b1bb167208e3640651ee4d03a58
    22. 22
      De Clercq, E. Potential of Acyclic Nucleoside Phosphonates in the Treatment of DNA Virus and Retrovirus Infections. Expert Rev. Anti-Infect. Ther. 2003, 1 (1), 21– 43,  DOI: 10.1586/14787210.1.1.21
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      22
      Potential of acyclic nucleoside phosphonates in the treatment of DNA virus and retrovirus infections
      De Clercq, Erik
      Expert Review of Anti-Infective Therapy (2003), 1 (1), 21-43CODEN: ERATCK; ISSN:1478-7210. (Future Drugs Ltd.)
      A review. The acyclic nucleoside phosphonates (HPMPC: cidofovir, Vistide; PMEA: adefovir dipivoxil, Hepsera; and PMPA: tenofovir, Viread) have proven to be effective in vitro (cell culture systems) and in vivo (animal models and clin. studies) against a wide variety of DNA virus and retrovirus infections, for example, cidofovir against herpesvirus (herpes simplex virus type 1 and 2, varicella-zoster virus, cytomegalovirus, Epstein-Barr virus, human herpesvirus type 6, 7 and 8), polyoma-, papilloma-, adeno- and poxvirus (variola virus, cowpox virus, vaccinia virus, molluscum contagiosum virus and orf) infections; adefovir against herpesvirus, hepadnavirus (human hepatitis B virus) and retrovirus (HIV type-1 and 2, simian immunodeficiency virus and feline immunodeficiency virus) infections; and tenofovir against both hepadna- and retrovirus infections. Cidofovir has been officially approved for the treatment of cytomegalovirus retinitis in AIDS patients, tenofovir disoproxil fumarate (Viread) for the treatment of HIV infections (i.e., AIDS) and adefovir dipivoxil for the treatment of chronic hepatitis B.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3sXlsFaisrw%253D&md5=5a86f3690fdca7c497c5887edee6dbb8

      [Crossref], [PubMed], Google Scholar

      Sofia, M. J.; Bao, D.; Chang, W.; Du, J.; Nagarathnam, D.; Rachakonda, S.; Reddy, P. G.; Ross, B. S.; Wang, P.; Zhang, H.-R.; Bansal, S.; Espiritu, C.; Keilman, M.; Lam, A. M.; Steuer, H. M. M.; Niu, C.; Otto, M. J.; Furman, P. A. Discovery of a β-d-2’-Deoxy-2’-α-Fluoro-2’-β-C-Methyluridine Nucleotide Prodrug (PSI-7977) for the Treatment of Hepatitis C Virus. J. Med. Chem. 2010, 53 (19), 7202– 7218,  DOI: 10.1021/jm100863x
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      24
      Discovery of a β-D-2'-Deoxy-2'-α-fluoro-2'-β-C-methyluridine Nucleotide Prodrug (PSI-7977) for the Treatment of Hepatitis C Virus
      Sofia, Michael J.; Bao, Donghui; Chang, Wonsuk; Du, Jinfa; Nagarathnam, Dhanapalan; Rachakonda, Suguna; Reddy, P. Ganapati; Ross, Bruce S.; Wang, Peiyuan; Zhang, Hai-Ren; Bansal, Shalini; Espiritu, Christine; Keilman, Meg; Lam, Angela M.; Steuer, Holly M. Micolochick; Niu, Congrong; Otto, Michael J.; Furman, Phillip A.
      Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (2010), 53 (19), 7202-7218CODEN: JMCMAR; ISSN:0022-2623. (American Chemical Society)
      Hepatitis C virus (HCV) is a global health problem requiring novel approaches for effective treatment of this disease. The HCV NS5B polymerase has been demonstrated to be a viable target for the development of HCV therapies. β-D-2'-Deoxy-2'-α-fluoro-2'-β-C-Me nucleosides are selective inhibitors of the HCV NS5B polymerase and have demonstrated potent activity in the clinic. Phosphoramidate prodrugs of the 5'-phosphate deriv. of the β-D-2'-deoxy-2'-α-fluoro-2'-β-C-methyluridine nucleoside were prepd. and showed significant potency in the HCV subgenomic replicon assay (<1 μM) and produced high levels of triphosphate 6 in primary hepatocytes and in the livers of rats, dogs, and monkeys when administered in vivo. The single diastereomer 51 of diastereomeric mixt. 14 was crystd., and an X-ray structure was detd. establishing the phosphoramidate stereochem. as Sp, thus correlating for the first time the stereochem. of a phosphoramidate prodrug with biol. activity. 51 (PSI-7977) was selected as a clin. development candidate.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXhtFKmtb%252FO&md5=33d371e557e9d70562a326f97798f45c
    25. 25
      Eisenberg, E. J.; He, G. X.; Lee, W. A. Metabolism of GS-7340, a Novel Phenyl Monophosphoramidate Intracellular Prodrug of PMPA, in Blood. Nucleosides, Nucleotides Nucleic Acids 2001, 20 (4–7), 1091– 1098,  DOI: 10.1081/NCN-100002496
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      25
      Metabolism of GS-7340, a novel phenyl monophosphoramidate intracellular prodrug of PMPA, in blood
      Eisenberg, Eugene J.; He, Gong-Xin; Lee, William A.
      Nucleosides, Nucleotides & Nucleic Acids (2001), 20 (4-7), 1091-1098CODEN: NNNAFY; ISSN:1525-7770. (Marcel Dekker, Inc.)
      PMPA, an acyclic nucleoside phosphonate analog, is a potent inhibitor of HIV. In the cells, PMPA is efficiently phosphorylated by intracellular kinases to produce PMPApp, the pharmacol. active metabolite. Despite its demonstrated antiviral potency, PMPA has limited cell permeability presumably resulting from the presence of two neg. charges on the phosphonyl group. To enhance intracellular concns. of PMPA, we developed a prodrug, selectively metabolized inside cells. GS-7340 (9-[(R)-2-[[[[(S)-1-(isopropoxycarbonyl)ethyl]amino]phenoxy-phosphinyl]methoxy] propyl]adenine) is a prodrug which is orally bioavailable in dogs as the intact prodrug and has demonstrated anti-HIV activity in cell culture of over 1000-fold greater than that of PMPA. The metab. of PMPA in peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMC), red blood cells (RBC) and plasma was examd. following exposure of whole blood to PMPA or GS-7340 at concns. similar to ones obsd. systemically following oral administration in dogs. Following 1 h incubation with whole blood, GS-7340 was stable in plasma, produced high levels of PMPA and its phosphorylated metabolites in PBMC but not in RBC. No intact prodrug was present in PBMC. The only other species present in PBMC was monoalaninyl PMPA. The levels of PMPA and the phosphorylated metabolites were over 20 times greater than those after incubation with PMPA. The dog and human blood data were similar. The intracellular levels of PMPA and PMPApp were roughly proportional to GS-7340 over a 10-fold concn. range indicating a lack of saturability of uptake and phosphorylation. Since PMPApp is the species responsible for antiviral activity of PMPA, the high intracellular levels of PMPApp should be an important indicator of greater clin. efficacy of GS-7340.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
